text:
WOW! I just made this for dinner tonight and my bf and I LOVED it!  This was SOOO easy to make.  The most time consuming part is slicing the onion / removing fat from the chicken (although I really didn't need to do the latter...). Use the best quality balsamic you can find - and afford (it REALLY does make a difference). Next time, I'll use a better quality balsamic (the dish was a tad tangy, but I like tart, so it wasn't an issue for me),  mix the balsamic, tomatoes & spices together BEFORE adding to the skillet (the spices tend to clump together otherwise) and add fresh minced garlic to the skillet as the breasts simmer (in lieu of the garlic salt called for).  If you are in a hurry or don't have all of the spices on hand, substitute Italian seasoned tomatoes for the plain ones and omit the seasonings alltogether.  This dish goes particularly well with garlic mashed potatoes and green beans, although, I think I'll try it with seasoned rice (i.e. chicken flavor) & steamed asparagus or broccoli next time to change things up a bit.

text:
Just a note to those who aren't fond of balsamic vinegar. Try adding some chicken stock in with the vinegar to equal the 1/2 cup measurement. It's a great way to cut down on the bite of the vinegarbut, still adds great flavor. So, those who might give up on this recipe try it this way and see what you think.

text:
I made this in the crockpot. Very easy to make. I prepped everything the night before and the next morning just popped everything in the crockpot and turned on low, the chicken was even frozen. I did use only 1/4 C. of balsamic vinegar as recommended in other reviews and I will add garlic cloves instead of garlic salt next time. Also, I will use chicken on the bone instead of boneless/skinless chicken breast if I plan on making this in the crockpot. The boneless chicken turned out dry. Other than that, the taste was very good.

text:
Loved this dish....  only made a few changes based on my family's preference:  No onion and didn't miss it.  Cut down the rosemary, basil, and oregano to 1/4 tsp each and omitted the thyme.  Threw in sauteed mushrooms and roasted red peppers I had prepared for another meal.  Now here's the secret, use the very best balsamic vinegar you can find as it has the smoothest flavor and will cut down on the tart vinegar flavor and you must use San Marzano tomatoes.  It makes all the difference....  Served this over angel hair pasta with a salad.  Family loved it!!!

I added mushrooms & topped off w/ some mozzarella cheese.  I also added a touch of brown sugar to cut the tanginess of the vinegar and also to carmalize the onions & mushrooms. I make this all of the time, and change it up by slicing the chicken and onions, adding slices of green peppers and serving over pasta...but I like preparing it as the recipe states as well. None
text:
Great recipe. I have made this several times. I converted it into a slowcooker recipe for a friend who had company coming over. I used 5 chicken breast halved into 10 pieceds and seasoned both sides with salt and pepper. In a hot skillet seared off both sides till browned working in batches. I then placed them in the slow cooker and poured the balsamic tomato and onion seasoned mixture over the top. Placed on low for 4-5 hours. (This next part is optional for a thicker sauce to go over polenta, mashed potatoes or pasta.) Remove the chicken and pour the sauce in a sauce pan add 2Tbs. tomato paste  and simmer till thickend. I really loved this method because I was able to make twice as much chicken, go to our kids football game and visit with her family and have a clean kitchen! Great technic!!!!!

text:
I made this a week ago and it was so good, I had to make it again. The more I make a recipe, the better it comes out and the more creative I can make it. I sauteed a clove of garlic(minced), sweet peppers, artichoke hearts and shaved onions in olive oil and a Italian blend dry seasoning. ((while my veggies are browning I made a mix of the balsamic vinegar, chicken stock, and brown sugar...***I doubled my sauce*** 3/4 cup balsamic, 1Cup chicken stock and 4tbs of brown sugar))I then salt and peppered my chicken and tossed it the the browning veggies and browned the chicken. Once everything is blended and browned, i tossed in some fresh chopped tomatoes and the sauce mix. I brought to a boil, lowered heat and covered for about 20 mins)**cook on low for longer if you would like your balsamic to thicken***   Yummy!! Paired with garlic and olive oil couscous and broccoli :)

My husband and I loved this recipe!  I've made this twice now in the past two weeks and it is just delicious.  However, I did use the half the recommended balsamic vinegar and substituted the other 1/2 with low-sodium chicken broth and it was even better.  I also used used 2 cloves minced garlic instead of garlic powder, fresh rosemary, fresh basil, and added fresh mushrooms when browning the onions.  Sooo good and will remain a favorite in our house.

text:
** I've seen the reviews since my original one years ago.  What kind of idiot would try to make this enitrely without balsamic vinegar?  Cmon, people! ** Wonderful!  Many thought it was a bit "balsamicky" -- here's what I did.  Instead of pasta or rice (too mushy to hold up to this), I boiled some potatoes, then cut them up and fried them lightly in a skillet in olive oil and a LITTLE salt and pepper, , making chunky hashbrowns (no seasoning -- the "drip-down" onto the potatoes from the chicken breast is sufficient and neutralizes the vinegar).  I like to serve this with steamed broccoli lightly drizzled in italian salad dressing, with a crunchy warm loaf of sourdough.

text:
This is the best chicken dish I've had! I left out the tomatoes. Put all other ingredients in my crock pot. Put a little olive oil in the bottom of the crock pot. I used 2 frozen chicken breasts and it only took 2.5 hours to cook. My husband raved about it! I did also subsitute the garlic salt for fresh garlic and did 1/4 cup of balsamic and 1/4 of white balsamic. I paired this with a mixture of brown & wild rice and steamed vegetables. We will be having again very soon! (Also, next time I'll make more of the sauce. It was very good on the rice and made it very flavorful!) Very easy and healthy meal!

country:

text:
Wow!  Talk about lip smacking flavors.  I made as is, and have made it again with personal preferences which are a very small departure from the original recipe.  As stated many times, if you go for the cheap balsamic vinegar, then expect a meager outcome.  This ingredient is the main focus of the recipe; might as well not skimp on it.  The first time I made as is, even my kids liked it.  They made a little face on the first bite but the tomatoes and spices really balanced the vinegar.  The only things that I have changed thereafter is really simple,
1- Added three cloves of garlic when cooking the onions
2- Combined the tomatoes, vinegar, and spices in a bowl and then added to the chicken.  It just kept all the ingredients together and coated the chicken better in my opinion.
I have made this several times and will continue!

text:
I decided to make this recipe, because I wanted to mix things up a bit. I am not a big fan of vinegar anything (normally), but wanted to make it as I thought my husband would like it. We BOTH loved it. I did change somethings after reading other people's reviews. I mixed a little less than 3/4 a cup of the balsamic vinegar with a cup of chicken broth and about 3 tablespoons of brown sugar and only a fraction of the seasonings called for and set aside. Then I browned the onions and once those were ready I added 2 teaspoons of fresh minced garlic then added the chicken to brown. Then I just added a can of diced tomatos and brought it to a boil and then ccovered and simmered it until it was done. This was different and very tasty. I even loved the chicken reheated!

I think that this was really good and would be even better with fresh tomatoes and herbs. I read a lot of reviews that said it was too sour. I think a big part of how sour the dish is would depend on the quality of balsamic vinegar used. A good quality balsamic vinegar is thicker and sweeter than cheaper ones and would be great in this dish. I can see how a cheap vinegar would make it way too sour..even for someone who loves vinegar.

This gets all stars as an EASY quick dinner that a married dude can zip up for the wife, three kids or mistress in no time flat. I just zipped this up on 11/17/14 and it will become a repeat at the dinner table.  I served with baked asparagus and garlic.  Toss in some Italian bread for the carboholic in your crew and you'll be good to go.

I drizzled some Alessi Balsamic Reduction on top when I served and it was great.  The bottle of merlot helped out as well!

Super easy recipe to make but I did feel like it was a bit to acidic between the tomato and the vinegar. I love balsamic vinegar but this was the kind of acidic that burns your nostrils! I'd recommend using only a quarter cup of vinegar and maybe cut it with something more savory like chicken broth.

text:
Yummy!! Made this for myself tonight and I greatly enjoyed it. I have to admit though that the onions were my favorite part:) So Good!! The only changes I made was to use fresh tomatoes and also I didn't have any rosemary or thyme. Next time I make it I will use fresh garlic, add extra onions, and make sure I have rosemary. It is better to cube the chicken or cut into strips in order for it to soak in the flavor so the middle part is not dry or tasteless. I ate with a side of green beans and roasted red potatoes. Delicious!! Will be making this again(soon). Thanks for sharing!! 
*UPDATE* ~ Double the onion, use fresh garlic and tomatoes, and add spinach and mushrooms. Awesome!!

text:
For us, this was only a 4.  It was interesting and edible, but some tweaking might improve it.  I followed the recipe, and it filled a 12 inch skillet.  I feel that the balsamic vinegar should be reduced to 1/4 c. and that crushed tomatoes should be used instead of diced.  The tomato pieces and the herbs sat on top of the chicken instead of blending into the sauce.  If I make it again, I will combine the vinegar, tomatoes and herbs before I add it to the skillet.  There was a lot of sauce left over.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I pretty much followed the measurements and ingredients from the original recipe except I used / added:

Fresh garlic cloves (6 - minced)
1 large can diced tomato (28 ounce)
1 can of mushrooms
1 can of artichokes

I chopped the raw chicken breast (4 med - lg ) into med - bite size pieces.  Sauteed the onion, garlic and mushrooms in a skillet with the olive oil.  While that's going, put the diced tomato and artichoke in a crock pot to get it warming (on High).  When the onion mixture is close to done, added the chicken pieces to give them a quick sear to seal the flavor / juices to help prevent drying. 
Add the whole skillet mixture into the crock pot, gave it a good stir and let it simmer on High for about 1 1/2 hrs checking periodically.  I also took the suggestion of adding a little bit of brown sugar to help cut the acidity from the vinegar and did this about 45 mins in.  Can't say the exact measurements of the sugar...maybe 1 T. total.  This dish worked out very well and the chicken was not dry!  It also had a very nice sauce!  I served it over brown rice.  This one's a keeper for us!

text:
Amazing.  The flavor of the balsamic is strong, so if you don't love balsamic, this probably won't be up your alley; we LOVED it.  The sauce reduced to such a nice thickness that I'd be reluctant to add stock, as some reviewers have done; more liquid seems like a bad idea.  I couldn't stop dipping bread in the sauce as I was putting away the sole leftover breast!  Bonus prize:  go easy on the garlic salt, and it's low-sodium.  You won't miss it because of the acid.

text:
Everyone really liked this dish and complimented on how moist the chicken was.  However, after trying it once the second time around I made a few adjustments.  I found the rosemary totally overpowerd the other herbs (and I'm not really a huge fan of it) so I cut it in half.  I put the oinions in raw because I don't like them too overcooked.  And lastly, I added more balsamic (because I love it) and doubled the tomatoes so there was extra sauce which I used on rice.  All in all, a very easy and yummy chicken dish!

text:
I love this recipe.  The only change I made was to make the balsamic vinegar a glaze that you add at the end.  In a very small saucepan, add 1 cup balsamic vinegar and 1 tbsp sugar.  Bring to a boil and then allow to simmer, stirring frequently, until it has reduced by 1/2.  It should stick to the back of a spoon.  Remove to a cool container.  Then I just drizzle the balsamic glaze over the finished dish.

text:
This was good but not spectacular.  I used 4 breasts & cut the balsamic vinegar back to 1/4 cup as suggested.  Also cut back on the spices a tiny bit & used fresh minced garlic instead of the garlic salt.  I served it with pasta and fresh grated romano but would use rice if I make it again since the sauce is watery & would be better absorbed into rice.  I think it might be good with some mushrooms & zucchini added to the sauce while simmering.  Also I let it simmer, covered for 1/2 hour since cooking it in the sauce keeps the chicken moist.  My son & husband both liked it so I think I might play around with the recipe & try it again with rice.  It's a nice change for a chicken recipe, thanks.

Well, it doesn't get much easier than this! One skillet which makes this easy to prepare and easy to clean up - perfect for a quick, yet delicious weeknight meal! I used thin sliced chicken breasts and minced garlic vs. garlic salt. I also opted to add in some sauteed mushrooms along with the onions to get in some extra veggies. text:
I made this recipe exactly as written. I was certainly edible, but the flavors weren't very well balanced. While I am a big fan of Balsamic Vinegar, and used a very good, aged vinegar, it overpowered the chicken and was the dominant taste. Next time, I think I'll try halving the amount of vinegar, supplementing with chicken stock, or water. Also, the Balsamic Vinegar significantly darkened the dish, making it much less visually appealing than the picture indicates.

userID:
3865752
Display Name:
NateInMpls
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6418559.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a couple changes which I thought would be amazing, and they were!  I saw another recipe on this site for a balsamic chicken and it used mushrooms, which inspired me to include mushrooms in this recipe.  I used one carton of fresh mushrooms, which I sliced into nice chunks.  I then added a lot of garlic granules to taste, and a little salt instead of garlic salt.  I was in a hurry so I didn't brown the onions and chicken, I just added everything into a small stock pot.  I thought that by adding everything at once, the flavors would be absorbed by the chicken as it's cooking.  By browning you may seal the pores of the meat so the vinegar can't get in.  Anyway, I threw everything into a small stock pot and simmered until the chicken was done.  There was a lot of moisture from the mushrooms, so I took a cup of chicken broth and added cornstarch, which I then used to thicken the juices in the pot into a delicious gravy.  It was excellent!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this 4 stars because it's a good recipe to start  with but to me, needed some tweaking to suit my taste.  Since some readers commented that the chicken was bland, I brined my chicken with salt, sugar, the spices listed in the recipe and vinegar.  Instead of 1/2 cup balsamic, I used 1/4 and added 1/4 of red wine.  To make the dish more saucy, I doubled the tomatoes using one can of rotel and one can of italian spiced tomatoes.  After the sauce simmered and the chicken was cooked through, I thought the sauce was a little too tart so I added a tablespoon of honey to balance the flavors.

text:
This was really good, made it just as the recipe states except cut in half and used small chicken breasts as there are only two of us.  Served over steamed rice with sauteed zucchini and mushrooms as a side.  Delicious and full of flavor.  I think next time though, I would use pull the chicken and onions out of the pan after browning and add the juices drained from the tomatoes and the balsamic vinegar and deglaze the pan, then simmer that down to about half and add back the chicken, onions and drained tomatoes to simmer for the last fifteen minutes.  Definitely don't overcook this, if you cook as stated the chicken will be perfectly moist.

text:
Wonderful recipe with no substitutions, but did add an extra onion.  Weight watchers - I figured out the recipe for points plus, and it comes to 5 points per serving for each of 6 servings. Tip- if you try to brown all the chicken and onions in a pan, they will all wind up steaming with no color.  I had to begin the browning of the onions, then remove them and brown the chicken before putting all back in pan. My husband and I both loved it.

Display Name:
FunwithFood

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6823763.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only used 1/4 cup balsamic vinegar as I thought the 1/2 cup would be too much. I was glad I had cut it back as it would have been too over powering a flavor in the amount listed in recipe (which is why I am giving only 4 stars). I actually think it would have been better using 2 to 3 tablespoons balsamic. I cooked this in individual foil packets on  a hot grill, 350 - 400, for 15 to 20 minutes. I did cut the chicken portions into 3 to 4 pieces prior to putting in foil packets. I did not pre brown the onion or chicken, just divided onion amongst the foil packets. I mixed the drained diced tomatoes with the balsamic, all the dried herbs, some salt and fresh minced garlic. This was spooned equally over the chicken and vegetables. I did add some red & green bell peppers cut into chunks. Then sealed each packet. Served over chicken flavored wild rice. Made a nice low fat healthy meal!

country:
None
text:
Outstanding but I ran into a few issues: 1) The chicken breasts were too large to be cooked in just 15 minutes, so the sauce and tomatoes/onions were getting close to burning. Since you're going to cut them up anyway at some point, might as well start out in cubes.  

Because my sauce was starting to burn, I poured in some white wine.  It did a fantastic job of taking the excessive tartness out of the balsamic vinegar while retaining the flavor of the vinegar in the dish.   I'd recommend reducing the vinegar by 1/4 and replacing the remainder with white wine.

My husband is in a food coma on the couch after eating his dinner portion, my leftovers, and his lunch leftovers. Oops.

Delicious! Hubby loves it, better than at a restaurant. Instead of 6 boneless breasts I had 4 large skin-on, bone-in breasts with some rib meat but just right for this recipe. Used real garlic and fresh herbs from the garden instead of dried, added some leftover fresh chopped tomato. Tender and tasty, after browning, simmered for about 1/2 hour because of the bones.  Next time, if I feel less lazy, will reduce the sauce down a bit. The browned onions start to caramelize. Yummy.

text:
You definitely need to be a fan of balsamic vinegar to like this recipe.  We are, so we liked this quite a lot.  I used only four chicken breasts, but left the sauce ingredient measurements the same so there would be extra sauce to serve over rice.  I felt that the sauce needed a little something extra, so I followed the recommendation of a member on The Buzz and added some minced garlic and a couple Tbs of cream cheese.  I also added a bit of kosher salt.  The resulting sauce was fantastic over brown jasmine rice cooked in chicken broth.

text:
Great Recipe; so healthy too!  Some people were complaining about the strong balsamic taste; I recommend making my version, which is diluted with chicken broth.  I threw everything from the recipe in my slow cooker, replacing the garlic salt with real garlic, adding in some mushrooms, and 2 cups of chicken broth, so it wouldn't burn.  You can either cook it for four hours on high or eight hours on low and it always turns out wonderfully (it makes your house smell super yummy too!).  It's easy and delicious, two of my favorite things!  This is now part of my regular recipe line up. Edit 8/22/15--This is also super easy when you pan-fry the chicken.  It does taste better when it's not made in the slow cooker.

text:
My Friendship Diner forum friends and I chose this as our January Community Cook-along recipe. So far the we've several ratings from "I loved it" to "I didn't care for this at all." From my rating you can see where I stood on this. First of all, altho I truly like every one of the ingredients in this recipe, I felt none of them were team players. I tasted every ingredient separately instead of having them engage to create a tasty sauce. I'm a huge vinegar fan but I felt there was just way too much of it. My S.O. liked it better than I, so at least that was a plus. However, I thank you Moonandback because there were members on my forum who gave this one four and five stars and that makes me happy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a bit too strong on the balsamic vinegar side for my tastes, but I think I might have made a measuring error. The taste was otherwise good and the chicken was tender. I served it over pasta. Just in case, I will start at 2 Tbsp, balsamic vinegar next time, and work my way up to the full half a cup as I taste the sauce. Because I found it too bvinegary, I looked online for a fix. I found a suggestion to add a pinch of baking soda at a time (stirring and tasting after each addition) to neutralize the vinegary taste. This worked quite well, so I thought I'd mention it in case anyone else has the same problem. It will fizz when you first add it, but just stir it in thoroughly.

Display Name:
Steve Z
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4159588.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Overall, I give this a 5 star rating.  It's a great recipe to make when boneless skinless chicken breasts are on sale for $1.99/lb.  I cooked this dish in a 12 inch Lodge cast iron skillet.  Like so many others, I recommend using only half the amount of balsamic vinegar.  4 oz of vinegar in my opinion is too overpowering for this recipe.  I cooked this with both the regular balsamic and white balsamic vinegar and both turned out very well.  With the exception of the basil which was added at the time of cooking, the other herbs were applied to the chicken several hours before hand and allowed to marinate.  I also like to have my share of veggies when eating, so I added diced bell peppers and mushrooms to the mix.  The peppers were added after the onions and the mushrooms were added at the very end.  I could have easily used a 28 oz can of diced tomatoes to the recipe.  Good with pasta or white rice.  Add some fresh grated Parmesan cheese to the top of the dish for additional flavor.  Personally, I love to add a big splash of hot sauce for some additional zip! Overall, it's a great recipe that requires minimal effort and time.  I'll definitely use this again and again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous!  I used 2 cloves of fresh garlic that I minced instead of garlic salt.  As another reviewer suggested, I cut my chicken breasts into about 1.5" chunks and dredge the chicken in flour, salt and pepper.  By doing this, the sauce thickened easily.  I also added approximately 1 lb. of mushrooms, a 1/2 cup of diced black olives, a can of quartered artichoke hearts, and about a 1/2 teaspoon of red pepper flakes.   I used a 1/2 cup of balsamic vinegar and 1 cup of water.  During the last 5 minutes of cooking, I added a 1/2 teaspoon of capers, as the sauce needed a bit of salt and an additional 1/2 cup of pasta water.   Served this over pasta, although I think it would be equally good with rice or roasted potatoes and a salad.    My best friend's husband owns a restaurant and is looking for new entrees for specials, and after eating this dish with my modifications he said that he would like to serve this at his restaurant.
Review:

userID:
2316497
Display Name:
Nancy B
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
52
favoritesCount:
134
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this in the crockpot, using boneless, skinless chicken thighs.  Omitted the olive oil, since I wasn't browning the onion and chicken.  Also omitted the garlic salt and used 2 cloves minced garlic instead.  Used 1/4 c. balsamic and 1/4 c. chicken broth as someone recommended instead of 1/2 c. balsamic. Placed the sliced onion in crockpot, put chicken on top (it was partially frozen still,) then mixed everything else together, adding 1 Tbsp. brown sugar and poured this over the chicken and cooked on low for 8 hours. After it was cooked, I thickened the sauce with 2 tbsp. cornstarch dissolved in 1/4 c. cold water.  Served it over brown rice.  It was delicious!  (Using the chicken thighs kept the chicken from drying out as mentioned in an earlier rating post.)  Definitely one I will make again, although I will leave out the brown sugar next time. My older daughter, who is also a fan of balsamic vinegar, loved this.

text:
TRY THIS!!!!  It is SOOOO EASY and it tastes like it's NOT!  Just to let you know what also works if you don't have some of the things on hand.  I used real garlic cloves instead of garlic salt and sauteed it with the onion.  I used 4 bone-in chicken breasts, and put them in the skillet skin down first, to brown them.  I turned the chicken back over once I added the other ingredients.  I used fresh oregano and rosemary.  I also used a can of STEWED TOMATOES instead of diced, which came out DELICIOUS.  ( I did NOT drain them) I let this cook while I got ready for work (maybe a half an hour to 45 mins since it had the bone in it), and it came out so good.  My husband LOVED it.  The balsamic cooked down with the tomatoes to make a GREAT sauce.  This is TOO EASY and TOO HEALTHY for you not to try!!!!

text:
Very good.  I used a tad less balsamic then called for and also added fresh garlic as others suggested.  I used 3 large Costco chicken breasts and left the sauce amounts the same.  Turned out very nice and moist, not too tart and I didn't use the brown sugar as others have said.  Served with mashed potatoes and creamed spinach from this site and it made a great well rounded meal.  By the way, the sauce amounts with using half the chicken called for was just barely enough to give extra on the top of the chicken and use for some potatoes as my hubby requires when i make any kind of sauce!!

text:
Prior to making this recipe I was seen as a pretty good cook. Now though you may refer to me as a domestic goddess because this recipe was simply divine. As others suggested I used a tad less balsamic vinegar, cut my chicken into bite size pieces, browned my chicken/onion/bell pepper(added a 1/4 cup bp) with white wine, and added minced garlic to tomato mixture. I added cooked white rice to the mixture which absorbed additional sauce. (If you do this only use enough white rice to absorb sauce or it will be too dry.) I am new to cooking and this recipe was easy. Thanks!!!

text:
Very good recipe. I'm a huge fan of balsamic vinegar, but even I thought it called for too much. I reduced the vinegar to 1/3 cup. I didn't want to use garlic powder so I sauteed the chicken with about 3 cloves of minced garlic... though it could have used more. I also added a half of a jar of marinated artichokes and a few portabello mushrooms. I served it over no yolk egg noodles tossed with a slight drizzle of olive oil and salt. This was packed with flavor and was very low fat. Will make again many times. Thanks!

Display Name:
Suzy-Q

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good with my adjustments, Hence the 4 stars. I read A LOT of the reviews before I made it.  I think this recipe was meant to be made with 'good',  i.e. aged, VERY expensive  balsamic vinegar, which IS NOT  that tart, and is kind of sweet. The less expensive balsamic is  nothing more than a fortified 'red wine vinegar', which may be why so many reviewers found this too 'vinegar-ee'. I'm not wealthy so I had the less expensive balsamic  and reduced it slightly on the stove before application.  Then basically followed the recipe, with the following changes, based on many of the reviews:  1/4 cup reduced balsamic with 1/4 cup water;  I just couldn't justify opening up a 32oz box of stock for a 1/4 cup. Added about 2 tsps brown sugar and about 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes ( I like spicy) to the 'sauce' which I mixed in a separate bowl first.  I also added about 1/2 cup diced sweet red bell pepper and added a drained 4oz can of sliced mushrooms to the onion sauté. I know that this is a lot of changes, and that many people get annoyed that a modified review is actually reviewing that person's changes and NOT the authors original recipe, and I used to agree with that.  However, I've gotten sooo many good tips, advice and opinions from said reviews and changes, that I've changed my mind. All  of my modifications came from the reviews I read, and I've been cooking for 45+ years.  You're never too old to learn.  Just had a dish of my finished recipe
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

Display Name:

city:

country:
None
text:
This was delicious! I blended all the ingredients for the sauce together (I have picky eaters in my household). I slightly browned the chicken in a dutch oven for about a minute a side, poured the sauce over top and then put it in the oven at 325 for 45 minutes. (My husband had called and said he'd be late from work. Otherwise I would have made it as written)
It worked out so well in the oven! I didn't cover it and a lot of liquid evaporated. It was a beautiful, thick sauce that was great over brown rice. The chicken was so tender we could cut it with a fork!

***Edit - I have made this multiple times now in the slow cooker! Just throw everything in and leave it on low for a few hours. Turns out amazing!! I can't get enough of this sauce!

text:
I tried this recipe, I changed it a little....I took two whole chicken breast diced them, prepared a little differently instead of garlic salt I minced a medium size clove of garlic and pepper. I also did as suggested by "Harpo" Nov 22, 2006  I used 1/4 cup of chicken broth and 1/4 Balsamic Vinegar. I sautéed 5 Brown Baby Bella Crimini Mushrooms (sliced removed stems)in butter in separate small fry pan with a little pepper for flavoring. I added these after they turned brown and I already added all other ingredients as cited above. I also served over Farfalle Pasta after straining I poured melted butter and minced garlic small glove.... and Garlic French Bread ....I'm glad I found this site, my household truly enjoyed this dish. I also only used 1/2 onion not to overwhelm the dish this easily serves a hearty portion for 4.

I cooked this in a crock pot. But I changed some things: 

I used garlic and onion diced tomatoes
No garlic salt, but I used fresh garlic
Fresh herbs of those that were called for
I added chicken stock
I used half a bunch of kale
A handful of small fingerling potatoes
A package of mushrooms, whole

I cooked on high for four hours, low for three. 

It was yummy. 

I give your original recipe 4 stars as well. Used it many times but baked in the oven. I did this as something a little different and just kept adding things because they were there and needed to be used up :)

text:
Super easy and tasty!  I didn't have Rosemary, so I subbed 1/4 tsp marjoram and 1/4 tsp sage. I also reduced the balsamic vinegar to 1/4 cup and added 1/4 cup chicken broth.  I browned 6 chicken breasts and removed them from the pan so I could sauté the onions and deglaze the pan with appx 2-4 Tbsp additional chicken broth. I also added 2 cloves minced garlic.  Served with rice and garnished with Parmesan cheese which really made flavors pop. Very happy to have another quick, gluten free recipe to add to my family recipe arsenal. Kudos.

text:
It was good--I'd make it again! I found it lacking in flavor though. I suggest adding a bit more herbs to the chicken before browning it. I also added baby portobello mushrooms, and they turned out amazingly! 

Lastly, increase the amount of thyme, rosemary, oregano, and basil you use! Add fresh garlic to the onions when you brown them.

It pairs well with angel hair pasta and green beans.

text:
ADD ONLY 1/4 cup OF THE BALSAMIC, AND ADD 1/4 cup chicken or vegetable broth! I followed this suggestion from another user, and it was AMAZING. If I used all the balsamic vinegar the recipe suggests, I think it would have been much too sour. I also substituted the garlic salt for 2 cloves finely chopped garlic. Absolutely delicious - better than restaurant quality! 
If you love mushrooms, I think those would go well in the sauce too.

I made this in the crockpot, which made it even easier and maybe even more delicious. - still browned the chicken, then deglazed the pan with about 1/3 cup water. text:
I've made this twice. The first time, I did half chicken stock, half balsamic vinegar, as some reviews said. The second time, I forgot the balsamic vinegar completely. My wife significantly preferred the second serving. I liked them both. I write this to affirm what others have said about the balsamic vinegar. If you like balsamic vinegar, great, make it as written. If not, no worries, just don't add it and it will still be awesome.

text:
I liked this dish but I would definitely tweak it next time around.  The only issue I had are: the chicken was way over cooked although i did remove it before the time suggested and I think there is too much thyme in the recipe.  I forgot the basil so I dont know if that would of added flavor.  Fresh garlic would be better too.
After I stated simmering the chicken and sauce i started reading the reviews and panicked because I thought it would possibly be too "vinegary."  I added a teaspoon of sugar to the simmering sauce and it was fine.  
I served this chicken on a bed of fresh baby spinach with fettuccine and green beans.  I topped the chicken and pasta with the sauce.

text:
Just finished this for dinner.  Loved it!  Took another reviewers suggestion and served it with garlic mashed potatoes
 and green beans, all went well together.  For my adjustments, I used only 1/4 cup balsamic, omitted the garlic powder and used two cloves of minced garlic instead, & used fresh rosemary.  The favors were wonderfully tangy and sweet.  The sauce reduced nicely.  Being the first time to make this I used a slotted spoon to put the tomatoes and onion over chicken not wanting to put too much sauce on.  After the first bite my husband and I went back to spoon the sauce over the chicken and potatoes.  An easy, quick & yummy weeknight dish.

Alanna Fox

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2700261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is AMAZING!  I made it for the family at the cottage and the reviews were over the top - my normally picky nephew exacts words was "that it rocked".  The only thing that I did to improve the texture of the chicken to make it more juicy was the following and the results were very positive.  I braised the chicken breasts for a few minutes on each side and then transferred the chicken, and added all the ingredients into a large baking dish and baked it for 30 minutes at 350. After letting it sit for 10 minutes, I then took each of the chicken breasts and cut them at an angle into diagonal medium sizes pieces and served on a platter in the sauce.  Cutting at an angle can add moistness to chicken breasts and allows the favor of the sauce to penetrate....plus easier to serve to kids and larger groups.

text:
The flavors in this recipe are wonderful if you use a good quality canned tomato and balsamic vinegar.  The spices blend perfectly with the vinegar and tomatoes.  Cooking wise, the time is WAY off for braising.  Braising is low and slow - in the alloted time, my chicken was super tough and even doubling the time only helped a bit.  Next time I'll use a more normal braising method but use the ingredients because flavor-wise, this is fantastic.

THIS was the best homemade chicken i have ever made!!! delicious!!
i used the italian stewed tomatoes as some one else mentioned and wasnt sure about using the juice, but definitely use it! it adds so much flavor!! and the chicken comes out so tender and juicy. however, my chicken took about 8-10 min, so keep an eye on your chicken ;) some pieces came out slightly over cooked but still delicious. my hubby was very impressed!! 
i also added a little bit of ground oregano and kept the rosemary and thyme (omitting the other spices since i used the italian stye which had the oregano and basil)
definitely going in the make often recipe box!!
thank you so much for a great recipe!!

text:
Amazing!  I made it with chicken tenders (on sale this week).  I used 2 cloves fresh garlic (grated with microplane, added during step 2) and seasoned chicken with salt and pepper.  I cooked onion first, removed from pan, cooked chicken, added rest of ingredients and stirred to combine before simmering.  I used 1 Tbsp Italian seasoning instead of the other spices (similar flavor profile, lazy cook).  I will make this again and again.  I am going to try varying the spices and using white balsamic vinegar to change it up (only because I may be making this once a week).  What a great recipe!  Very easy to make and great flavor!

text:
I used Italian stewed tomatoes (cut up a bit) in place of plain diced, 3/4 tsp salt and 1/4 tsp granulated garlic in place of the 1 tsp garlic salt, and halved the thyme (because all I had was ground). I replaced half of the vinegar with red wine once, bit I much preferred the balsamic tang of the original; might be good with just a little wine mixed in instead of replacing so much of the vinegar. Mushrooms would be an awesome addition and I think I'll try that next time, maybe with the chicken cut up first as per a few reviews; it would be easier to eat with pasta that way. This has definitely made the rotation.

text:
I really enjoyed this dish and I am always looking for a low calorie meal so this was great for me; however, my husband did not like the balsamic taste. I added mushrooms to this dish and served with a side of mashed potatoes and garlic bread, super yummy! I followed others suggestions and diluted the balsamic in chicken broth (1/4 cup balsamic:1/4 cup chicken broth, and added a tablespoon of brown sugar. I think 1/2 cup of balsamic would be a little too overpowering. I also mixed all the ingredients for the sauce in a separate bowl before pouring it onto the chicken. I only added a small dash of rosemary and used fresh oregno and removed before serving. My only complaint was that the sauce was very thin.

I have made this dish probably a dozen times and just realized I never rated it.  This dish ALWAYS turns out great and is requested often!  The recipe is very forgiving on ingrediants too.  Tonight I used dried onions instead of fresh and added mushrooms - and served over wheat pasta.  Yum!  I frequently add chopped garlic too. text:
Edible, but not delicious. I love balsamic, but the flavor in this dish just wasn't very good. I followed the directions exactly and the end result was unexpectedly bitter. Strong vinegar flavor, strong oregano flavor and dried out chicken. If I do try making this again, I will make sure to use top notch vinegar as one reviewer suggested. I will also cut back on the spices (especially the oregano). Finally, I will check the chicken after 10 minutes of cooking since the breasts were overcooked at 15. Sorry I can't rave about this recipe. I'm glad so many others have enjoyed it.

text:
This recipe is great, my family raved over it! I had to used sliced stewed tomatoes instead of the diced ones, but that didn't make any difference in terms of taste. If I could do it differently, I would put in 1/3 cup of balsamic vinegar and the rest chicken broth, because I thought it was a bit strong (though my family doesn't want me to dilute it, they love it how it is!). The wide opinion among my tasters is also that it tastes better over the pasta instead of the rice, though the suggestion for pairing it with mashed potatoes sounds REALLY good. Thanks, this is a keeper!

text:
I made this for my Husband (not a chicken fan)and his parents. Everyone raved about how amazing this dish was.  Based on previous reviews I made a few minor changes: I added a little minced garlic while browning the onions. I used about 1/3 cup of the balsamic vinegar and topped it off with a little chicken broth to make the 1/2 cup measurement. I also used a pre-blended Italian seasoning instead of those listed as that was what was already on hand and left the rosemary out, only because I do not care for its flavor. I served the dish with green beans and seasoned potatoes (using a Grocery store seasoning packet) baked in the oven. This was a fabulous dinner!

text:
GREAT!!! It's much better with Bone-In Breast!!! Bake Breast 45 mins, drain, cut 1/2. Drain tomatoes, up Vinegar to 2/3, mix all ingredients then simmer on stove to poured over cooked breast, simmer in oven 30+ mins at lower heat in tight fitting pan and cover w/ foil. My 9 yrs olds + hubby loved it more with bone breast over boneless.  Breasts taste better the longer they sit the sauce. A KEEPER!!  Great with Rice...use extra sauce/juice to top rice...might want to increase sauce.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am trying to cut out excessive amounts of sodium plus I needed something easy and different, and this recipe fills the bill on all points. I used plenty of Mrs. Dash Salt-Free Table Blend and garlic powder on the chicken pieces (cut into strips) before browning in an oven-proof skillet along with the onion in 1 T olive oil and 1 T butter. I mixed no-salt added tomatoes with only 1/4 cup balsamic vinegar, the herbs and, on a last minute whim, 2 tsp. brown sugar. I then poured this mixture over the chicken and put the skillet in the oven at 350 for about 20 minutes while I made rice. Since I only used 3 large chicken breasts halves, I had quite a bit of sauce, so next time I will add a couple of sliced yellow squash to the skillet along with the onion. Thanks for posting this, Moonandback!

userID:
5978507
Display Name:
vuchi2000
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I invited friends for dinner on short notice and I needed a recipe that didn't require a trip to the store. I was able to pull this together with pantry items and it was a hit. I made several adjustments but the result was amazing! I used fresh rosemary and substituted some pre-made pesto since I didn't have any basil on hand.  I also cut the vinegar to 1/4 cup and added 1/4 cup vegetable stock. The sauce was a bit tangy so I added about a tbsp of sugar to balance the flavor. Finally I stirred in aprox 2 tbsp of flour while the sauce was simmering to thicken it. I served over angel hair pasta with an arugula salad. Fantastic!

text:
I did this one a little different, I marinated the chicken in the spice-mix , 1/4vinager, chopped onion, and 1/4 cup of oil for at least 4 hours in a ziplock bag in the fridge(turn it once or twice). Then I browned the chicken on both sides, no need to add oil it already has it, and added the tomatoes and remainder of the marinade. Simmered until juices ran clear, and served with carrot rice recipe from this site, wow nice combo (I thought)

Wow this really surprised me.  Im not a huge tomato fan but I love balsamic so I gave it a whirl.  I used the pre-spiced diced tomatoes and thickened up the sauce a bit at the end with some corn starch.  If you do this, be sure to combine the corn starch with some of the hot liquid BEFORE adding it to the pan or you will just get a clumpy mess.  Very tasty and I will definitely make it again.

This was absolutely delicious! I don't know why someone would make a balsamic dish if they don't like balsamic vinegar, but I am a fan of that kind of vinegar and I thought it was extra-tasty with the tomatoes. I have used both fresh and canned, and it always comes out perfectly with lots of flavors. I have left out the onion on occasion with no decrease in the yumminess. The seasonings are awesome, too. I love that this is an easy chicken dish with so few ingredients! It has become a regular dish in our house for nights when I want something quick, easy, and healthy.

This was very yummy and easy to put together.  I'm glad I took the advice of previous reviewers and cut the Balsamic to 1/4 cup and added 1/4 cup of chicken broth.  I love Balsamic Vinegar, but it would have been way too strong with a 1/2 cup. userID:
615195
Display Name:
Aspiring Chef Rita
isPro:

744

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/146.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DELICIOUS! EASY!  Only used 2 very plump chicken breasts but used the amounts called for in preparing 6 breasts (except for seasoning the chicken breasts themselves - just sprinkled on some Goya seasoning).  Since the breasts were thick I slowly browned them on one side for 5 minutes, turned them over and browned other side and added the onions at that time. If I had added the onions in the beginning they would have burned.  I used diced tomatoes that had oregano, garlic and basil already in it so I just had to add the thyme.  At other reviewers suggestions, I used 1/4 cup of balsamic vinegar and 1/4 cup of chicken broth.  Good suggestions - the vinegar was not overwhelming.  I simmered (uncovered) for 15 minutes on one side and 10 minutes on the other side because of their thickness.  While it was simmering the liquid reduced itself and gave a nice thick sauce to spoon over the chicken.  Thanks submitter.  This is a keeeper.

This was very easy and delicious. I dusted my chicken thighs with a little whole wheat white flour after seasoning with the pepper and garlic salt so sauce would be a little thicker in the end. After I added the tomatoes I sprinkled the sauce with a little bit (1/2 tsp) of sugar to balance the tang out a little bit.   I absolutely adore Balsamic Vinegar so this recipe was great and two out of my three kids ate it and like it!!!  I served it with Trader Joe's green beans and Lundberg Parmesan risotto.  Easy weeknight dinner for a busy mom. Thanks!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/45218.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This chicken dish was excellent!  It had lots of flavor from the balsamic!  It was just great!  I did like a lot of others and added half vinegar to half chicken broth.  But after tasting it while it was simmering, I wanted more balsamic so I probably ended up putting in almost the whole amount that it calls for.  The key is to use a good quality balsamic.  So when your in the grocery, pay that little extra for a good bottle.  I did saute in some garlic and only had two large chicken breasts.  It actually was perfect with two.  I wouldnt use more than four chicken breasts for this recipe because then you wouldnt have enough sauce.  And we love the extra sauce!  I served this with the pasta pomodoro recipe on this site.  It paired excellent with this dish!  It actually almost reminded me of a popular dish at fridays restaurant called chicken bruschetta.  Great recipe, 5 stars, this is a favorite!  Thanks for the recipe!

Made this the other night for my family.  I will admit to some mild trepidation about using all that vinegar (especially after reading prior reviews), but I needn’t have worried.  I followed the recipe exactly, and everyone loved it.  My husband was still talking about it the next day!  The chicken was tender, and the sauce was beautiful and delicious.  I served it with parmesan couscous (Near East brand), and it was the perfect accompaniment, giving the dish a sort of Middle Eastern flavor. The only modification I made was using all fresh herbs.  Will definitely make again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6261287.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wish I had read the reviews regarding the tanginess of the balsamic before I cooked this;  I don't have any regrets, I loved the flavor, but it was certainly tart, which I would have liked to have been toned down a little.  I was hoping the sauce would be more a reduction, so I may just reduce the sauce alone to have with the leftovers.  In order to keep the chicken tender, I dredged the chicken w/ salt/pepp/garlic powder/flour.  I happened to be baking cauliflower mashed "potatoes" to serve with this, so instead of simmering in the pan, I browned the chicken in the pan w/ the onions but cooked the rest of the way in a 350 oven for about 20 min.  It looked beautiful coming out with the tomatoes and onions browned on top.    Def a keeper, but one that I would like to tweak to suit my own tastes in the future, probably just to make it less tangy (with the addition of a bit of brown sugar) and make a reduction sauce.

Try this with bone-in chicken thighs!  I had to discard quite a bit of fat and it cooked considerably longer, but it was fantastic!  I browned the chicken first and then deglazed the pan with chicken stock before sauteeing the onion and fresh garlic(don't use garlic salt).  I followed the recipe from there, but tossed in a tablespoon of butter at the end to add a sheen to the sauce and to help it stick to the chicken.  Excellent!

Display Name:
TUNISIANSWIFE
isPro:
False

142

431
favoritesCount:
411
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/933710.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a sinch to prepare with ingredients one tends to have on hand and can be made at a moment's notice.  I don't use garlic salt.  Instead I crushed 2 cloves and put it in the end of the onion/chicken saute so it would not be too brown and get bitter, and added salt to taste.  I then proceeded with the rest of the recipe.  I left out rosemary(don't care for it) and added a can of the Italian diced tomatoes as well as the other spices as listed.  I don't like bland; if one likes things with a little zip then I would suggest adding a bit more of the spices or use the Italian tomatoes as well.  I love the sweetness that Balsamic gives to any dish or salad and usually sub it in place of other vinegars.  If one finds it too vinegary, sometimes adding some BROWN sugar to a sauce will help cut it.  Would definitely make again.  Served it over basmati rice and it was nice.  *If one likes the blend of chicken and balsamic, might want to try the Chicken Breast Pierre recipe here on Allrecipes...it is somewhat similar.

I've made this dish several times now and its delicious as is, but I've tweaked it to my tastes. I accidentally pureed the onions in my ultimate chopper but it made it better! I added tomato paste to thicken the sauce and cook everything with at least five cloves of fresh, minced garlic (I looove the garlic!). I also cut the chicken into bite size pieces and let everything simmer for 30 minutes to an hour (however long it takes for my fiance to come over) and serve over bowtie noodles with garlic crescent rolls on the side. Perfect!

text:
This was a great quick recipe. I followed advice from previous reviewers and pounded the chicken and cut it into pieces and also added mushrooms. I also used the full 1/2 cup of balsamic and it was perfect. It seemed to just be a matter of letting it simmer long enough (the full 15 minutes)to tone down the owerpwering taste of the vinegar. I also sauteed roasted red peppers and a clove of garlic along with the onion. Next time I'll probably try artichoke too as some suggested. Thanks for the recipe!

Very very good.  I only had 3 boneless skinless chicken breasts, so browned those.  Changed vinegar to 1/4 cup per other reviews, and used 1/2 tsp rosemary, all other herbs used as shown in recipe.  Also added 1 can of mushrooms drained.  Excellent!!  Served with white rice.  Only gave 4 stars cause i wish there would have been some more juices.  Next time I may add maybe 1/2 c chicken broth.  Hubby doesn't usually like chicken with sauces, but he liked this.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly and was not very happy with the results.  The vinegar flavor was way too powerful for my taste.  If I make it again (which is doubtful,) I will definitely reduce the balsamic vinegar to about 1/4 cup, maybe less, and replace with either chicken broth or water.  I served this over brown basmati rice, which helped to salvage the chicken.  My other complaint is that it isn't a very pretty dish -- sort of muddy looking.  This recipe is rated really well by other users -- it was very quick and easy to make --and if you like the taste of balsamic vinegar, you'll probably really like it.

I have made this recipe at least 30 times.  It's my favorite all time recipe!   It is perfect for entertaining because you can prepare it ahead of time and guests think you have been slaving in the kitchen all day.  I do recommend a good Balsamic vinegar.  That is the key!  I follow directions to a T.  Bon appetit!

text:
Wow!!! I was a little worried that the vinegar would be too strong and overpowering. Especially after simmering for a long time and seeing the chicken change in color to a dark burgundy. Nope. The flavor was perfect! The only vinegary taste was the tomatoes and they were perfect too. My family loved this, it was easy to make, and it was a healthy dish. I highly recommend it. PS- I know people tend to add their little alterations. Try it they way it is posted first. No need to alter this recipe.

text:
So flavorful and quick!  I used Aceto Balsamico Di Modena which is a thicker balsamic vinegar. It is a little more expensive than other balsamic but it's the only one my Italian husband likes. I only buy Bell and Evans brand chicken and don't have to drain fat.  This is a keeper....use good quality products and you won't be disappointed!

text:
I've made this a few times and it's great every time.  I like some more vegetables so I cut up some red pepper and throw it in at the same time as the onions.  I also take the chicken out with about 5 minutes left, cut it into cubes and throw it back it.  The chicken absorbs the sauce better and I've found it's tastier this way!

I changed the recipe a bit because I didn't have onions, guesstimated with spices, halved the recipe, and I used crushed instead of diced tomatoes, but it was AMAZING. At first, I tried the "sauce" and the balsamic was way overpowering (my cheap Kroger balsamic), but after I let it cook for not even five minutes it was TO DIE FOR. I would even make just the sauce again to use in pasta. The chicken was incredibly moist and flavorful. I loved it! Thanks!

This recipe is scrumptious!! I've made this several times and have had rave reviews every time. The only change I personally made was to cut the rosemary in half. I serve this chicken with garlic rice and it's a great combination. Thanks for the recipe. LOVE IT!!

text:
I tried this recipe Because I did not want dry bland chicken breast. I used salt and garlic powder. I added some minced garlic (garlic lover). It came out perfect not acidic at all. The balsamic vinegar with the browned onions gave it a milder sweeter flavor. I did cook it a little longer than suggested maybe 20 minutes and I let the juices come to a boil before I cut the temperature down.
I served it with quinoa and salad. My husband loved it and the calories were right in line with what I was looking for.

text:
I followed the instructions and the ingredients, but I must have gone wrong somewhere.  The chicken came out great, but the process was a little nerve wracking, it could be me, I don't like to cook chicken because I'm scared of undercooking it.  Anyways, when I tried to brown the chicken, it never browned, instead it kind of boiled in its own juices, even though I only had the 2 tbs of olive oil in the pan.  Then I felt like it took forever for it to cook, and I kept waiting for the liquids to reduce, but they never did.  The chicken turned out great though, and the sauce was really good, even my husband loved it, but I did follow the instructions to a T and had some difficulty, but it was worth it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made this (still eating it this second =P ); have to say it came out with perfectly moist, delicious chicken. Made two tiny changes: first off, instead of 1/2 cup of balsamic vinegar, used 1/4 cup balsamic vinegar and 1/4 cup balsamic vinaigrette so it wouldn't be quite so overpowering in strength. The second change was to add some cayenne in as well for a bit more bite to make up for the slightly weaker balsamic bit used. It was quick, easy, cooked the chicken perfectly, tasted great. I'll be experimenting with this more in the future to work up some personal variations, as I have the strong suspicion that it could be even greater than it already is with a few more tweaks to the spices. I also really have the feeling, as eating this, that it could use a little soy sauce as well. Still, very good recipe, highly suggest trying it out! ^.^

I hardly ever cook, and by hardly I mean never. Decided to try this and I must say, it was a GREAT recipe even for someone who is pretty foreign to the kitchen. I only had to buy one or two spices but I had everything else in house. Pretty quick and easy to prep. Display Name:
Dave Regan

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1869586.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe but the directions are all wrong IMO. Start with a heated, oiled pan and add the onions, cook until brown add the other ingredients (except chicken) and simmer for around 20 minutes. Season and cook the chicken in a separate pan, deglaze with a bit of red wine and add to other ingredients. Simmer for a few more minutes. This way you have time to caramelize the onions and marry all the ingredients without overcooking your chicken. I agree with others to cut the balsamic with chicken stock if it's too tangy. Adding a tablespoon or two of sugar will help with this too.

I made this a bit simpler - I used a can of Italian style diced tomatoes (has the herbs already in it) and didn't add any extra herbs. country:
None
text:
I love the flavors and simplicity of this recipe, but I must admit that using whole, boneless chicken breasts made for a dry piece of meat.  The second time I made it, I bought thinly sliced chicken breasts and barely seared them, took them off the skillet, and reintroduced into the onions once the onions were browned.  Much better!  Just add to the sauce, because buying the thin pieces makes more surface area.  I recommend making it in a pot rather than a skillet, if you do it this way, so all of the chicken gets into that yummy, tomato-y, balasamic bath!

text:
This was so good!  Make sure you are using good balsamic vinegar, the quality will make or break this dish.  It shouldn't be too tangy if you use good balsamic.  I took another reviewer's suggestion and combined the tomato, balsamic, and spices and then added the mixture to the chicken.  I also added a little minced garlic.  I only needed to simmer the chicken for 10 minutes.  I served the chicken on top of spaghetti, which absorbed the extra sauce.

text:
This recipe was just ok, but my adult son liked it; my husband said it had too much tomato.  I should have used real garlic, and I should have used more pepper.  I did add chicken stock to 1/3 c. of balsalmic vinegar, and I was glad I did.  It would have been too strong.  On the other hand, it tasted too tomatoe-y.  But that's just me, I'm not crazy about chunks of tomato.  I agree with someone else who said this is really good without the chicken!  I used Quinoa, and it was very good with the sauce.  I cut up chicken, because I had thin chicken breasts, and I didn't like the texture.  That isn't the fault of the recipe, though.  I think I prefer cooked tomatoes and balsalmic vinegar separate.

text:
Yummy! I stumbled across this recipe while searching for another.  It was easy, healthy and delicious.  I wasn't sure about the vinegar but took a chance and so glad that I did.  I subbed 2 cloves of minced garlic for the garlic salt (not a fan of garlic salt) and used chicken breast tenders.  The sauce was exactly as written.  I thought we'd have leftovers but hubby had 2 big servings and proceded to pack the leftovers for lunch with just a bit left over.  I served it with rice and a wedge salad.  I think this would be great with pork tenderloin or chops, too.  Will definitely make again.  Thanks!

This was excellent! What I did differently:  I used fresh garlic, and sauteed with the onions for a few minutes before adding the chicken.  I also used boneless/skinless thighs.  I also used a very good aged balsamic ( I think this is key) and braised the thighs for about 25 minutes until the vinegar started to thicken.  Great with mashed potatoes.

text:
I wanted to like this so much more than I did. I added a small sprinkle of Truvia sugar to the balsamic vinegar, and I'm so glad I did. It cut down on the tang and brought out the smooth flavor of the balsamic. The tomatoes were actually pretty delicious because they soaked up so much of the balsamic flavor, but the chicken itself was a little bland. Even the next day, after soaking in the balsamic/tomato juice mixture, the chicken was STILL bland!! I was a bit disappointed.

text:
I thought this was great because I love balsamic. Since I have two small children I add a bit of honey to cut out the tang that was a little to intense for them the first time I made this. I also add mushrooms, bell peppers, garlic and fresh herbs from my garden. If we want some kick a squirt of rooster sauce is perfect. I brown the chicken in my Dutch oven and then add all the other ingredients and pop it in the oven at 350. I leave the skin on the chicken except for my husbands piece because it grosses him out. Thanks so much for sharing this recipe.

text:
Fabulous! I'm a huge fan of balsamic vinegar, so this was right up my alley. The flavors came together very nicely. This is pretty tangy, so keep that in mind if that's not your thing.

A few modifications. Based on a previous review, I added minced garlic to the skillet right before adding the balsamic vinegar (instead of seasoning chicken with garlic salt). Also based on a previous review, I mixed the balsamic vinegar, tomatoes, and herbs together before adding to the skillet. Finally, I used fresh tomatoes instead of canned.

Had this with rice. Was sad when my plate was clean...

text:
My husband would give it 5 stars.  It was good to me, but I wasn't scrambling for more--though I will definitely put it in rotation.  Followed others: only used 1/4 cup balsamic vinegar (used Wegman's store brand and it was fine) and 1/4 cup chicken broth and added fresh garlic.  I accidentally thought I had diced tomatoes, but after I'd already started cooking, I realized that it was actually tomato sauce.  So I used just half the can.  I mixed the sauce, vinegar, and spices together and set aside.  I placed chicken directly on top of the onions and garlic and moved everything around every now and then.  Simmered it in the sauce for just the requisite 15 minutes.  Tasty!

text:
This dish is packed with wonderful flavor. If you don't like strong flavors then don't make this dish.  Followed the recipe exactly.  Used a large white onion which was perfect.  Followed the advice of another reviewer and mixed the balsamic vinegar, tomatoes, and spices all together and then poured over the chicken.  I also found it difficult to cook the chicken and onions together so I cooked the onions and then browned the chicken and added the onions back in the last few minutes of browning.  Hubby went crazy over this dish.  Has already requested we make it again.  It was very moist and delicious. We dipped our crescent rolls in the sauce.  Might serve over some white rice or pasta next time.  Thanks for sharing this wonderful recipe.

This was interesting, but good.  I'm not a huge fan of balsamic, so it was a bit much for me.  My husband loves balsamic, and loved this.  He'd say five stars, I'd say three, so we're going with four.
EDIT: We made this a second time, using fresh tomatoes (3 medium) and fresh basil - DEFINITELY made a difference.  I'd still say 4 for the original recipe, but with our changes, a 5-star.  We served it with brown rice pasta (my husband has to be gluten-free) and green beans.  We're making it again tonight!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night, and as some users suggested, cut way down on the balsamic vinegar. I used one large chicken breast which I cut in half, and so reduced balsamic to 1/8 of a cup. I also added more thyme and 4 cloves of minced garlic. I wanted mine to be served with rotini pasta, so I added tomato puree (one large carton) and 1/2 of a can of chicken broth. I cut the chicken into pieces and removed from heat while the sauce cooked for about 25 minutes. I then re-added the chicken and stirred in the pasta and 1/2 of a cup of freshly grated Parmesan cheese.

userID:
9223178
Display Name:
kristenskitchen
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/827335.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i thought this was a fantastic dish! i did make some adjustments as i didn't have all the dried herbs on hand. i also just cooked this for 1, myself, and it came out perfect and i ate everything in the pan. i didn't have garlic salt, i just seasoned my chicken breast with a whole bunch of seasonings in my cabinet. i used garlic & herb, caribbean jerk, and poultry seasoning. i didn't have canned tomatoes on hand, i just diced up some cherry tomatoes i had in the fridge- worked perfectly. i also bought some cheap balsamic vinegar- i bought publix brand- and i thought it was fine. not too tangy or anything. i also threw in some diced garlic to the pan when i sautéed my onions. i also added a squeeze of chili pepper paste (its in a tube) that you can find in the veggie section of your supermarket. when i added my chicken breast to the pan and after i added the vinegar, tomatoes, etc., i just threw it in the oven for 10 minutes at 350 degrees. 2 minutes before it came out, i added a thick slice of mozzarella cheese to it (i had the deli section at publix slice me a big piece) and viola! it was fabulous! i even added some fresh basil to it when i put it on my plate and it was delicious. fantastic meal!! will keep this one around! and i think the chili pepper paste added a nice, small, kick of heat to the dish!

text:
I made this last night and it was delicious!  I followed the recipe with two exceptions.  First, I grilled the chicken on the bbq then cut it up and added it to the sauce, and secondly, I used fresh rosemary.  I served it on a bed of rice with a side of green beans.  This is so simple to make, but does not sacrifice flavor!  I should also add that I only used three chicken breasts as it was only for two of us.  However, I didn't change the quantity of any other ingredients because I wanted a sauce for the rice.

text:
Very quick and easy - and healthy to boot!  Only had cheap balsamic on hand, so I halved it and added a pinch of sugar, but I think it would've been best with the whole amount.  Subbed garlic for the onion and tomato sauce for the diced tomatoes due to personal preference.  Flavor was good - I was afraid the spices would be overpowering, but this was not the case - and chicken was juicy.  I highly recommend pulverising the rosemary with either a spice grinder or a mortar and pestle for better texture.  Served this with whole wheat penne and roasted asparagus,  Delicious!

text:
I made this for dinner tonight and both hubby and I really enjoyed it. The flavors blended beautifully, and the chicken stayed moist. I served it over hot couscous with a green salad and we both felt spoiled. The only change I made was to use onion powder instead of fresh onion, because I was out. The fact that it was still so good in spite of the missing fresh onions tells you what a great dish this is. I did mix the tomatoes together with the herbs and balsamic vinegar in a bowl (as a reviewer suggested) before adding to the skillet--I think this is an easy way to make sure all the herbs get distributed evenly. I bought a good quality aged balsamic recently and I think it truly makes a difference since the vinegar is such an integral part of the dish. Will make this often. Thanks for a great, easy dinner, Moonandback!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this recipe, I followed it exactly and we thought that it was a bit too balsamic-y for our tastes. After the chicken was cooked through, I let the sauce simmer a little longer and added some brown suger to cut back on the balsamic taste. 

The next time I made it I halved the balsamic and substituted the remainder with white wine. The result, I thought, was much smoother than the original recipe. 

Both times, however, I used garlic instead of garlic salt, and sauteed the garlic with the onions (which I did before adding the chicken so that the onions would be nice and soft by the time the balsamic, tomatoes and seasonings were added). 

It needed a little tweaking but overall a delicious recipe.

text:
Love this! Prepared this differently than the recipe directions- First we cooked the (red) onions until lightly browned and soft in a mixture of butter and EVOO. Set aside. Used 8 pieces of chicken (thighs/legs) rubbed with seasonings then browned in the pan. Set aside in a glass baking dish. Topped with a can of fire-roasted, diced tomatoes and a cup or so of homemade pasta sauce (made with red wine, parm, plenty of seasonings- was on hand from the freezer) then added a few oil-packed, sun-dried tomatoes and drizzled on the balsamic vinegar. Baked in a pre-heated 350F oven for 40-50 minutes. Served with "Mushroom Rice Pilaf" from AR.

Display Name:
asianchick
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has become one of my family's favorites!  I use chicken thighs, personal preference, and let me say they were falling off the bone tender!  When making for the kids I follow the advice of others and halve the balsamic vinegar and add 1/4c chicken broth.  We also prefer using stewed tomatoes instead of the diced...the last time I used diced it was a little too sour for us...a blitz in the food processor before adding the tomatoes to the pan makes the sauce thick without being too chunky.  Loved it with potatoes or garlic rice!  Very pretty dish that would be suitable for company, besides who doesn't want a new way to cook chicken.
Review:
Rating:
5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really great recipe. We did a couple extra things to spice this recipe up.
1. No pepper/garlic salt
2. Cut/flattened the chicken breast, and stuffed it with soft Blueberry Cinnamon Goat Cheese.
3. Rolled the breasts up and toothpicked them shut.
4. Baked at 375F until center was done. (Approx 25 mins)
5. Sauteed onions with spices until golden, the added tomatoes and balsamic vinegar.
6. Served with sweet potatoes, asparagus, topped with sauteed onion/tomato over chicken.

Deliciously sweet and exotic.

text:
Thank you for this original recipe for chicken...always looking for a new way to prepare.
I did make a few changes (personal taste).  I used 5 chicken thighs for the flavor,  I added a few large, sliced shallots to the onions and later on, added several large, diced garlic cloves. I first used 14.5 oz can of tomatoes and added about a cup of fresh from the garden and still found it needed more, so I added an additional 14.5 oz can of tomatoes.  This made the volume right, but had to tighten it up a little with a flour/sauce slurry...did the trick!  I served it over fettucine with fresh steamed green beans, drizzled with olive oil and sprinkled with fresh romano...mmmmm....This will become one of my family favorites.  Thank you for sharing!

text:
Holy cow this is fantastic!! Made it last nite and no leftovers! I used bone-in, skin on chicken breasts, seared them in a skillet w/evoo and thru them in the slow cooker. I used the onion, fresh garlic and some fresh mushrooms and caramelized all then added to the chicken. I used italian seasoning and poured the tomatoes over. I let it cook on high, was able to remove the bones and skin, made some garlic mashed taters and green beans it was so yummy. I think next time I will use cremini mushrooms for even a deeper flavor, oh, I also added a smidgen of dark brown sugar which really brought out the balsamic flavor without adding more vinegar! So easy to make and so yummy to eat definitely a keeper, Thank you so much!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-07-25T19:45:03.23

text:
this recipe was really good, brilliant. but honestly i cant have that too often, every now and then is good enough for me, nothing to do with the recipe itself, just personal taste. i replaced garlic salt with 3 garlic cloves, and added salt to the chicken to taste as with the pepper. I didnt have a can diced tomatoes so i finely chopped 4 tomatoes, crushed 3/4 of the quantity and added 2 tbsp of tomato paste to them. i did mix the basil, oregano, rosemary, thyme with the crushed tomatoes as other reviews suggested, to avoid clots. i didnt decrease the quantity of balsamic vinegar, but i did add 1/4 cup water to the mixture while simmering. My family loved it.

text:
I loved this recipe and so did my family.  I did do a couple of things differently from the recipe.  I caramelized the onions first and browned the chicken on each side then added the other ingredients. Oh! and I used fire roasted diced tomatoes instead of plain.  Anyway after I added all the ingredients to the chicken and onions I let it cook low and slow instead of the 20 minutes that the recipe says, our chicken was all but melting in our mouths.  I wish I had thought to take a picture.  But serving it with rice is a GOOD addition!  I will be using this recipe again!

None
text:
This was okay but I probably won't make it again.  I followed the recipe and tasted the sauce once it had time to simmer.  The vinegar gave it a sharp bite and I had my doubts that my family would enjoy that.  I took suggestions from some reviewers and added some brown sugar.  That helped but still was not enough.  Some reviewers suggest adding chicken broth.  I did not want more liquid so I added some chicken bullion crystals instead of broth.  That helped balance the flavors and I served it like that with white rice and steamed broccoli.  They all ate it but none of us were crazy about it.  The leftovers are untouched in the fridge.

userID:

Display Name:
JANER01

31

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good!  If chunking the chicken rather than using whole breast halves, you don't need to cook it as long (found that out the hard way).  I know some hate people who change recipes, but I did use fresh garlic instead of garlic salt, I chopped rather than sliced the onions, used fresh basil and rosemary as well as fresh tomatoes from the garden.  We also chose to thicken it with a little cornstarch/cold water as the kids don't do as well with super juicy sauces.  If you use fresh tomatoes and garlic, you will need to add a little salt to taste.  We served it over rice, with a salad.  Overall, very good and relatively fast, and going into the regular rotation.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe exceeded my expectations, we absolutely loved it. The chicken was so tender, and the onions just melted into the sauce. I am very very timid with balsamic vinegar, so I used just over a quarter cup balsamic and added an extra can of tomatoes. For our tastes it was flavored enough, I'll attempt a full half cup next time with 2 cans to follow the recipe closer. The tomato chunks seem to soak up the vinegar flavor and you get a great burst of tomato-balsamic flavor in each piece. The herbs complemented everything nicely. I will definitely make again, maybe someday with up to the written amount of vinegar: thanks so very much for sharing!

text:
I cook a lot with balsamic, so I had real concerns that 1/2 cup would overpower this dish.  I used equal amounts of chicken broth and balsamic to measure 1/2 cup, which gave us the balance of flavor we were looking for.  Used chicken cutlets which cook very quickly, so next time, I'm going to brown the onions a little bit before adding the chicken.  Easy dish with nice presentation.  We enjoyed this recipe.

Oh, my!  This is delicious exactly as published!  I've also used this as a marinade for grilled chicken with delicious results!  A tip for those who don't like the vinegary taste:  Buy the most expensive balsamic vinegar you can afford.  It really does matter!  Williams-Sonoma has great reasonably priced balsamic vinegar, but Costco's balsamic vinegar gives you more bang for the buck and is *almost* as good!

text:
Overall, this was an enjoyable meal.   My 6 year old and 4 year old both cleaned their plates.  I made the following changes:  I used a can of tomato sauce instead of diced tomatoes (my kids hate chunks of tomato), 1/2 tsp Rosemary and 1/4 tsp Thyme.  I think the diced tomatoes would have tasted better, and I will try it next time.  I will also brown the chicken with freshly minced garlic, rather than using garlic salt.  I served it over brown rice.  A good meal that was quickly prepared.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/400086.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great weeknight recipe!  I made a few changes by cutting the chicken into (just larger than) bite-sized chunks.  About halfway through browning the chicken I added a clove and a half of diced garlic and when adding the tomatoes and balsamic vinegar I also threw in a can of (drained and rinsed) quartered artichoke hearts - thanks to the suggestion of another reviewer.  While the chicken was simmering in the vinegar and tomatoes I broiled some asparagus, cut into 1-inch pieces, with olive oil, salt & pepper, and threw them into the chicken just before I took it off the stove.  I served this over brown rice.  It received rave reviews from my boyfriend (who has a self-proclaimed discerning palette). 5 stars! This will definitely go into the rotation!
