text:
YUM!!!  This was soooo good! I used chicken thighs (we like them better).  I caramelized the onions in the pan then removed them to brown the chicken.  After the chicken was browned I threw on the onions, some shitake mushrooms, Kirkland balsamic vinegar (from Costco), fresh garlic, rosemary from my garden, and since I didn't have any canned tomatoes, I used almost 2 cups diced fresh tomatoes with 1T tomato paste.  This was absolutely fantastic!!  I will definitely make this again and again.  It was not too "vinegary" it was absolutely wonderful!!

text:
I am on a low cal diet and finding new recipes has become a challenge. This is a perfect chicken recipe that has plenty of flavor. I didn't have a chance to read other reviews before making this dish but luckily I know how powerful balsamic vinegar can be and cut it in half. I also cut the rosemary in half. It still looked as if it may be overseasoned but luckily it was not. I would season to taste as a suggestion. The sauce is wonderful. I will use the leftovers for a pasta dish tomorrow night. Quick, easy and flavorful. I definately will make this again.

text:
I used two chicken breasts, the same amount of tomatoes and onion and reduced the vinegar to 1/4 cup. Seasoned the chicken with sea salt and black pepper and added two cloves of garlic (one minced, one crushed) in the beginning. Soo delicious! I usually don't like white meat chicken but this cooking method makes it soo moist and yummy. I spooned the extra sauce over noodles (and have some left over!) and added a side of green beans. Love love love!!

text:
I feel like this is more of a 3.5 star rating, but since that's not an option I will go with my husband's advice. First of all, I read through many many reviews and decided to cut back on the balsamic vinegar...despite the fact that I really like balsamic vinegar & I used a good kind. I am glad that I did because it was pretty "tangy", which is what my husband liked about it. I, on the other hand, liked the taste but thought that the vinegar overpowered the other herbs & seasonings. What is the point of adding all the other stuff if all you can taste is the vinegar? So, I will be making this again and will probably play around with it...good starting point though.

My husband does not like balsamic vinegar so I took the advice of another reviewer who said not to write this recipe off if you do not like balsamic vinegar. I used 2 tablespoons of balsamic and then added chicken broth to equal 1/2 a cup. It was delicious and my husband and I both loved it. Even my picky 2 year old ate it. We were able to taste the balsalmic vinegar in the dish, but it was not overpowering for my husband. We will definatley be making this again.

country:
None
text:
I love balsamic vinegar in combination with almost everything, so I was really looking forward to this recipe. When I was cooking it, however, I got rather alarmed as the kitchen started to smell only like very strong onion and tomatoes - which normally I like, but not when so overpowering. I was really worried that that smell was what the sauce and the chicken would taste of. When it came time to eat, I grabbed the chicken, leaving as much sauce as I could in the pan. The amount remaining on the chicken was excellent, and the chicken was juicy and tender. However, I served this with rice, and I was rather disappointed that the sauce (including all the tomatoes, etc) was doomed to be thrown away. Also, although in the end it turned out well, I don't know if I'd make this again, just because the sheer smell was so off-putting to me.

I was looking for a dish that matched one I had in a local eatery and this is it.  IF your sauce is too tangy - you did not use a good quality Balsamic.  It should be almost like a syup.  I added some veggies to the sauce to camalize before I added the chicken so the chicken wouldn't get too well done.

text:
MMMMM good.  I cooked a whole ton of this and ate it over whole wheat spaghetti every night for a week and didn't even get sick of it!  The only slight change I made was to use the "italian style" diced tomatoes that include some herbs and then add a little extra seasoning (dried oregano, garlic powder, salt, pepper, I think) while cooking.  Very delish, chicken was so juicy, and sauce was tangy and wonderful.  I am a big fan of balsamic, so I loved the tart flavor.  Will definitely make again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely fabulous!!!! One of my favorites that I've gotten from this site! However, I did tweek it a little bit. I seasoned with just salt and pepper and sauteed fresh garlic cloves in the pan before adding the chicken, omitting the chopped onion (don't like to bite into a piece of onion, just a personal preference) but adding onion powder to the seasonings. I used diced tomatoes that were canned with garlic and olive oil and were already seasoned so I cut back on the basil and oregano and omitted the rosemary and thyme (keep in mind if your tomatoes aren't pre-seasoned you won't have to do this. Also instead of plain balsamic I used an aged balsamic-chipotle glaze and it was incredible!!! I think the spice truly made the dish, so definitely add some if it's what you like!

text:
Very good! I just made this for my boyfriend and myself. He loved it and so did I. I omitted the rosemary because I didn't have any on hand, and accidentally dumped in too much oregano and basil, but it still tasted awesome. Also, I heated the olive oil, added some minced garlic, and on top of that seasoned the chicken with garlic salt and freshly ground black pepper. It was nice and quick and easy to make, perfect for a weeknight. Paired with leftover scalloped potatoes and steamed green beans, which proved to go together well.

text:
This was a great recipe!  My husband and I loved it, but of course, I made some changes.  Instead of garlic salt, I used 3 cloves of fresh garlic, and added a pinch of salt to the chicken.  I also used red onions which gives it a slightly sweeter taste (to combat the tang of the vinegar).  I also didn't add the tomatoes (I used 3 fresh plum tomatoes) til the end in order to keep them somewhat firm.  Served it over garlic mashed potatoes and it was a hit!  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
awesome! Must make a again.  I used this recipe as a rough guide. Used 2 large chicken breasts, 1 onion, 2 cloves garlic, 2 T olive oil, 1/2 big can of diced tomatoes, good big swig of balsamic vinegar, generous couple of pinches of italian herbs, added one can of artichoke hearts. cooked for 20 minutes after braising, uncovered, and chicken was nice and tender. Served with greenbeans and rice.  Boyfriend loved it.

text:
Yum!  This was a tasty and easy one-pan dish.  I really like the fact that recipe can be made without having to make an extra trip to the store for ingredients.  I used fresh herbs since I had some that I wanted to get rid of and added approximately three T. black olives (that was all I had left in the fridge) and 1/3 c. chopped mushrooms.  Artichokes would be good to add as well; I always like to make recipes healthier in any way I can, so extra veggies often find their way in!  :) To combat the vinegar taste that many reviewers mentioned, I used one T. brown sugar and the taste was just right.  I prepared this for my mom and two sisters and everyone loved it.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Wow!!! This one's a keeper. There is so much flavor (but not overpowering) in this. I didn't think it would have that much flavor from the simple ingredients. One of the best things about this for me is that I almost always have all of these ingredients on hand. I used a red onion and added an extra 1/2 teas. of freeze dried chopped garlic in with the other spices. You could easily tweak this recipe to your liking, maybe throw in some thinly sliced green or red bell pepper, or even use steak in place of chicken. I took some of the leftover pan juices, onions and tomatoes and mixed with some plain brown rice for a complementing side dish. Chicken was perfectly tender. Keeper!!

This was very good! 

I used the full amount of balsamic vinegar. I omitted rosemary and thyme, as I didn't have them on hand. I cut back significantly on the onion - only used about 1/4 onion.

The chicken was among the most moist that I've ever had.

I was shy to try out this recipe, as I'm not a fan of vinegar of any kind, but decided to give this recipe a try. How could I not, with such rave reviews?

I served the chicken with broiled asparagus and a crunchy artisan bread.

Everything was delicious. Thanks for the fantastic recipe!

text:
I followed the recipe exactly, but left out the thyme because I didn't have any. It was absolutely delicious and I don't think that sugar needed to be added to the sauce as others have suggested. I served this with seasoned rice (from a package) and veggie medley (frozen) and the combo was great. Next time I will either marinate the chicken in the vinegar, or cut the chicken into strips before cooking. The sauce did not penetrate the whole chicken breast, so it could have been more flavorful. I just now had the leftovers - cut the chicken into bite-sized pieces and let it soak up a lot of the sauce as I warmed it in the microwave. Delicious!

text:
I cut the chicken breasts into tenderloin sized strips.  I sprinkled salt, pepper, and garlic powder on the chicken, then marinated in the balsamic vinegar.  In the pan, I used olive oil and a tablespoon of butter.  I also used minced garlic along with the onion.  When I tossed in the chicken and remaining vinegar that didn't soak in.  With a dash of brown sugar in with the spices and diced tomato, the taste wasn't too tart but just right!  I plated the chicken and added grated Parmesan.  The sauce was fantastic with pasta, and I served green beans too.  This was quick and easy, but most importantly, satisfyingly tasty!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made several amendments to this recipe: I used fresh garlic cloves instead of garlic salt; I used fresh tomatoes instead of canned tomatoes; and I added LOTS of fresh cilantro. Also, I allowed the pan to simmer until the balsamic vinegar became thick. The resulting dish was delicious. Next time, however, I will use more onions. My brother, who does not care for balsamic flavours, rated my dish a 7.5 out of 10. I will be making this again (though I may decrease the amount of balsamic if my brother is joining me for dinner).

Update 11/2/14: I just made this recipe again with half garlic powder and half minced garlic (jarred), fresh tomato, and no thyme (didn't have any). I followed the rest of the recipe closely and cooked until chicken reached 165F and the balsamic vinegar reduced. The resultant dish was delicious! I love that it is quick, healthy, easy, hearty, and oh-so-good!

Recommendations:
-To avoid overcooking or undercooking chicken, use a meat thermometer 
-Consider increasing herbs/balsamic mix by 50% and cook in a wide, shallow pan to avoid long reducing time. 

Verdict 
I will make this again and often!

text:
The only down side of this recipe was that I used the rest of my high quality balsamic vinegar for it.....was it worth it?  YOU BET!!  This was really very good.  The only alteration I made to the recipe was that I used fresh basil and I didn't have any thyme:(  When I make it again I will probably cut down on the balsamic a little bit and will cut down on the oregano.  It was the one spice I could taste above the rest.  I will also up the basil.  The way I see it olive oil, basil and tomatoe is a classic and I'll go with 2 tablespoons of the basil and cut back on the oregano to 1/2 teaspoon.  I'll also serve this with pasta.  It was great and the best part is I have everything in my staples.  Thanks for sharing!

text:
My husband and I are crazy about this recipe!!  The balsamic vinegar adds amazing flavor to the chicken--in fact, I've found that adding all three spices is unnecessary, and typically just add a small amount of basil OR oregano.  The recipe is "special" enough for company and easy enough to throw together at the last minute--I typically have these ingredients on hand.    I echo other cooks who have posted--if you aren't crazy about balsamic vinegar, this may not be the recipe for you.

Surprisingly very delicious. I cut my chicken into strips, and instead of using the full teaspoon of garlic salt, I did 1/2 tsp. and then did a bit of additional garlic powder cos I am trying to cut back on my salt intake. I was out of oregano, so I did 3/4 tsp. of Italian seasoning and upped the rosemary a bit. We ate this over whole wheat spaghetti, and it was delicious. I think using high quality balsamic makes a big difference.

This is a great low cal entree! I served it with pasta & a salad & it was really great. However, I did have to alter it some. I added some wine (I use it in almost everything) with the chicken while sauteeing. I also used only fresh herbs & tomatoes. After following all the instructions, I just felt like it was really missing something. At that point I would have given it about 3 stars. I added about four cloves of garlic and it was exactly what it needed! What a difference. It was excellent after that. I will definitely be making this often!

text:
I scaled this recipe down to 1 serving, and I don't think it came out as good as if it was made with the original serving size.  Basically, if you make this for one, add a lot more balsamic!  And also brown the chicken first before doing the onions, since there are so few, and wait a little bit before putting in the tomatoes (I used fresh Roma, also, which I thought was better than canned; also used fresh basil).  I agree with the other reviews that adding garlic would be fantastic.  I cut up the chicken and put it over angel hair, then made a balsamic reduction sauce to pour over it since I didn't think there was enough.  That helped a little, but maybe I just really like balsamic more than the average person.  So, I give it 3 stars for this time but I think it has the potential to get 5 next time :)

text:
This recipe is so easy to make and tastes really really good!  I think the next time I will use 1/3 rather than 1/2 cup of balsamic vinegar though.  I love balsamic vinegar, but the amount that this recipe calls for was too much for me.

This recipe took only about 20-25 minutes to finish from start to finish.  I ate it on top some whole grain pasta with garlic bread on the side.  Delicious!  

As other reviewers stated, it doesn't look so pretty, but on top of pasta it looks beautiful and tastes great.  It tastes like something I might purchase at Olive Garden or The Cheesecake Factory.  This is one food that also smells great while you are cooking it!  

I am bad with leftovers.  I can usually eat a dish once and can't eat it anymore until after several days.  This will be coming out tomorrow for lunch though!  This will definitely become one of my regular menu items.

text:
VERY VERY GOOD! Absolutely a 5* recipe! My husband fell in LOVE with the sauce! He'd like to use this sauce anywhere a recipe calls for marinara, and loved it on the basmati rice I made to go a long with the chicken.  I did add appx 2t cornstarch (mixed with cold water) to the sauce to thicken prior to serving. The only problem I had was that the chicken didn't get fully cooked in the amount of time the recipe called for - I ended up covering the skillet and cooking about 10 minutes longer...they were kind of large pieces, so, if you want to stick to the cooking time of 15 minutes, you may want to flatten the chicken prior to cooking.  Excellent and very different! Thank you for sharing this tasty recipe!

text:
This was delicious. The only change I made was adding a can of artichoke hearts to the dish when I added the tomatoes (which had roasted garlic in them). The chicken was done before the sauce reached a consistency I liked, so I took them out and cooked the sauce alone maybe another 10 minutes. The vinegar taste is strong, but I happen to like balsamic vinegar. If you aren't sure if you like this, I would say to cut back on the vinegar the first time you make this just to be safe. I served this with bulgar wheat and it was a perfect compliment to the tasty sauce.

city:

region:

country:

text:
I've made this as written before and those who didn't like it were right.  It's very easy to make and ok, but it is flawed.  After reading some of the comments, I fixed it last night.  Below are the required changes to ingredients, preparation, and technique.  Not quite as easy to make, but mostly adding small details which makes all the difference.

To the recipe, add about 2 cups of sliced mushrooms,  2 – 4 cloves of garlic (minced), ½ cup of white wine, 1 cup of chicken stock.  Also, use fresh rosemary (chopped) instead of dry and triple the amount.  (the dry rosemary ends up leaving an unpleasant texture of little wooden sticks in the finished dish).  (Afterthought:  Adding a good handful of golden raisins  to the cooking liquid while reducing might add a nice sweet accent to it.  I'm going to try it next time.)

You may want to reduce the amount of vinegar to 1/4 - 1/3 of a cup instead of 1/2.  Some found that much vinegar too tart and they have a point.  It’s up to you.  I made mine with 1/3 of a cup.  The added wine and stock help to cut the sourness as well.

New Procedure

1)  Liberally season both sides of chicken breasts with kosher salt, pepper, and garlic powder (do not use garlic salt)  Set aside in refrigerator for at least 2 – 3 hours.

2)  Combine the can of diced tomato, balsamic vinegar, white wine, chicken stock, and all dried/fresh herbs in a small bowl and set aside.  (Add a couple of teaspoons of kosher salt if you use unsalted chicken stock, which I su
Review:

Might be better served with crusty bread and veggies verses noodles or rice and veggies.

Display Name:
nahnii
isPro:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavor of this dish was amazing. Slightly tart and slightly sweet and packed with flavor. Next time however I will be making the following changes to take it to the next level. First, I will be cubing my chicken like others suggested. I followed the instructions exactly and it was difficult to properly brown the onions  and mix all the flavors with these big pieces of chicken in the way. If you're going to stick to the original instructions and to the keep the chicken breast whole, I suggest mixing the tomatoes, spices, and vinaigrette in a separate bowl before placing in the pan over the chicken. Next, I will be cutting down the cook time in half. I cooked my chicken following the directions, and I ended up with really dry chicken. And last, I'll be serving this over a bed of angel hair pasta, or some mashed potatoes. Depending on the mood I'm in. P.S. choose a really good vinaigrette!! Great job to the original poster for an awesome, easy, and low cal recipe!

I used a tablespoon of butter with olive oil while sautéing the onions then added sliced button mushrooms to the pan when onions were almost done. Mixed in the rest of the ingredients and had that finished ahead of time. Chicken was cooking in the instant pot sous vide style which I had added garlic salt, pepper and a bit of paprika too. When it was time for dinner we popped the chicken on the grill for appearance and searved with sauce over the top. Very good and I’m sure it’s good as written too I just like the idea of adding mushrooms and making ahead without drying out the chicken.

userID:
771095
Display Name:
MsBee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5

0

15
favoritesCount:
126
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5160905.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was, overall, pretty fantastic. Super easy to make! My family loves balsamic and we use it in a LOT of recipes, so when I chose this, I knew what to expect. Another reviewer pointed out that 15 minutes is really not nearly long enough for a true braise, and I agree, hence the reason for 4/5 stars. 

I had boneless, skinless chicken thighs, so that's what I used. I halved the *entire* recipe because I was only cooking for two and had enough on hand for that and a single day's leftovers. Other than the protein (and I'm not sure I'd do this with breasts, but maybe with pork chops), I made this mostly as written. My minor changes were to season the breasts with salt and pepper and Italian seasoning before browning, I used fresh minced garlic, I added a splash of sherry in the balsamic, and I let it braise for at least 30 minutes (I didn't set a timer, but it was more than 30, less than 45). That let the vinegar *tang* mellow as it cooked and I ended up with a deep, rich sauce that was fantastic on the chicken. 

Next time I will likely add the mushrooms several folks have suggested, but otherwise I like this recipe a lot and we'll definitely make it again. Might even adapt it for the crockpot.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-02-05T03:07:31.66
helpfulCount:
0

I made this dish exactly as instructed after watching video and reading carefully. I am so disappointed!  First, the definition of "braising"  (from Food Network) on anywhere else, is low and slow.  Not 15 minutes.  if you want it tender, it takes TIME.  The sauce was good (reminded me of the Liver & Onions my mom used to make).  BUT the chicken was as hard as a rock.  If the chicken breasts were slice thinly, this would probably be good, but you still need to simmer for 35-45 minutes and make sure you have enough liquid in your pan,.

RedWineChic

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6145419.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish was amazing. Made it for a dinner party and everyone just loved it. 
I used kosher salt and dry brined the breasts for several hours, brought them to room temperature before putting them in the skillet. While frying the chicken, I had the tomatoes (28 oz can San Marzano), 1/2 c balsamic vinegar,  fresh oregano and basil and tablespoon of brown sugar simmering Added sliced mushrooms and onions to the skillet and caramelized and then added the sauce and continued simmering for another 15 minutes. Served over rice with buttered asparagus .  Amazing!
Will definitely be making again and again.

I loved this recipe! I had to change a few things, but overall it was the same dish. I cut everything by 1/3 (for 2 people). Instead of wasting a whole can of tomatoes, I used 1 medium chopped Roma tomato. Also, I added mushrooms, sliced portabellas to sauté with the onions. It turned out great! I think one thing that makes a HUGE difference in this dish is the quality of balsamic vinegar used, I used a high quality imported version. It has a less acidic, tart taste, and is slightly sweet.

text:
This is fabulous tasting but I changed the cooking method..  Saute the onions and fresh garlic in the olive oil till just soft. Add the dry spices and stir until fragrant.  Add the rest of the ingredients and simmer for 5 minutes.  Pour on the chicken and bake for 20.  So good!  I am making it again tonight and cooking it over chicken tenders.  As stated be sure to use a good balsamic!

Rating:

userID:
21242061
Display Name:
KAK
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
159
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5679855.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for 2 people. Used 2 chicken breasts, cut in half. I cut the seasonings in half and used only 3 tablespoons of good balsamic vinegar. Used the full can of diced tomatoes and 1 medium onion. Also added a small can of mushrooms. 
Sauté the onion and mushrooms, adding 1 tsp of brown sugar and 1 Tbls.  of butter. When the onions are softened and beginning to brown, add all seasonings and 1 tsp minced garlic.  Remove the cooked veggies from the pan into a small bowl. Add a bit more oil and brown the chicken 4 minutes per side. Remove the chicken. Put the veggies back in the pan and add the cam of diced tomatoes. Mix thoroughly and nestle the chicken in the pan. Simmer, covered until the chicken reaches 165F. Serve over rice.

It was pretty good. My kids ate it with rice and they are fairly picky. I added a few cherry tomatoes to the canned tomatoes and a couple mushrooms (because, come on, mushrooms!)
I bought the fancy B.V. and did a 75% balsamic/25% chicken broth mix because I was worried that the kids might find it too strong. It's still pretty strong even diluted. Next time I would slice the chicken after searing it to get more flavor into the breasts and a more tender braise.

region:

country:
None
text:
This was okay but maybe that's because I used a cheap balsamic vinegar from Walmart, that was more tangy than sweet, as other reviewers have said a good balsamic is very sweet. So based on other's suggestions I used only half the vinegar and replaced the other half with a beef (not chicken) broth, and also added brown sugar at the end. I used whole garlic cloves minced instead of the garlic salt. We ate this over spaghetti. I felt this was lacking flavor. We added more pepper and also lots of parmesan cheese which improved the taste. I probably wouldn't try this again unless I buy a better balsamic vinegar.

text:
This dish was easy to make and it made the chicken very moist and flavorful, but the rest was not that great. If it was a little bit sweeter, we might have liked it better. If I were to make it again, I would either put in less vinegar (and add some chicken broth) or add a little bit of sugar to it, and I would definitely use fresh garlic plus salt instead of garlic salt. Also, I might prefer it over pasta. We put it over rice and it didn't particularly mesh well.

userID:
2917439
Display Name:
Jaims Nemeth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

21
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2117389.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight. It was fairly quick and easy.  I chopped my onion and some cloves of garlic in a food processor.  Seasoned and browned my chicken in olive oil, added onion/garlic and sweat them, then added can of tomatoes, a little water (2 Tbsp, to get sauce out of can) and GOOD balsamic vinegar. I think this is key, as a poorer quality would likely lead to a more acidic tasting dish.  I truly braised it (in a closed container) on my stovetop for about 30 minutes.  The boneless chicken breasts cooked perfectly in that ime. I turned over the chicken half-way through.  When nearing the end, I left the lid off and allowed it to simmer to try to cook down the liquid.  In the end, it was savory, slightly acidic and somewhat carmelized--adding a nice touch of sweetness to the dish.  Served it over steamed rice with a side of sauteed green beans.  Will definitely make this again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3209699.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe in an attempt to use ingredients I had in my pantry. I didn't have chicken breast thawed but I had cans of diced chicken. I prepared the recipe as it was written but used 2-12.5 oz cans of diced chicken instead of 6 chicken breast. I googled the proportions of diced chicken to chicken breast. It is 1 chicken breast is approx 4 oz. diced. I still seasoned them the same and browned them a little before the onion. All I had was Italian style diced tomatoes and still used the same spice amounts. I probably could've reduced the oregano, basil and thyme. It was kind of strong. Next time will get regular diced tomatoes. My family LOVED it! Even my autistic son who hates most things loved this... Major win for football Sunday meal. Served with jasmine rice and seasoned French style green beans.

text:
Yummy, easy and quick.  I accidentally picked up crushed peeled tomatoes instead of diced.  Still worked out great. Figured that I'd get creative and throw in some sun dried tomatoes.  Don't think that made any difference, could have done without.  Don't waste your time adding anything else.  It has  more than enough flavor as is.  The balsamic is VERY dominant.  I love balsamic but even still,  I think next time I'll go with a  1/4 cup instead of 1/2 cup.  Skipped serving it with a carb but would have been great with pappardelle, polenta or even mashed potatoes.  Don't think I'd serve it with rice. Did serve with with garlic roasted broccoli (can find recipes on this site). Yum.

text:
I made this for my husband, mother and I and we all highly enjoyed it. I served it over rice and added diced garlic when I cooked the onions. I didn't have diced tomatoes so I used stewed instead. We all liked the stewed that I will continue to use them however, I will do TWO 14.5oz cans next time because we like tomatoes and one can was not enough.  It was a fast and simple recipe and will become a staple. I have a recipe similar to this that you basically put it all into the crock pot and cook on low so the chicken doesn't dry out. I really didn't think this took too much more time then that but if you all want to do it that way, I can say its tasty. Just don't use all the oil in this recipe in the crock pot.

text:
I absolutely love this recipe!!! It is so delicious and gives the chicken an amazing taste. I had leftovers and cut up the chicken and put it in a salad the next day. I made this twice and I made it a little different the first time because I didn't have diced tomatoes, and I have to say I liked it better. Instead of the can of diced tomatoes I used a can of tomato sauce (not prepared, just the tomatoes). I also mixed in a little tomato paste and mixed all of this with the vinegar and seasonings before adding to the chicken and onions. The sauce came out thick and creamy...absolutely delicious!!! I let this cook for awhile until the chicken was so tender it broke apart when I touched it with the fork. MMMMMM!

country:

text:
OMG!!! OUTSTANDING!!! I made this recipe  yesterday,  &  was totally  impressed! Totally  restaurant worthy.  I used all ingredients,  exactly  according  to the recipe.  The only thing  I did differently from the recipe,  was put the sauce  &  seasoning  in a separate  pan, simmered  it for about  30 mins,  so the spices in the sauce  was evenly blended,  then poured over the chicken  (cooked according  to the recipe), and simmered for another  30 mins.  Mushrooms  would  be a nice addition  to this recipe,  but not needed. There's enough  sauce  to put the chicken  &  sauce  over rice,  egg noodles,  or whatever  you desire. I have  been  using  this website  for years, &  this is my first review.  (FB  makes it easier  to log in &  write reviews). I found  this recipe,  when I was looking  for something  healthy  to support  my husbands diet). I know  some reviews said  they used chicken  broth &  vinegar). I recommend  cooking  it exactly  as stated, then  make changes  if you're  not happy.  The vinegar  is not overwhelming, (for my family  anyway)! Enjoy!!!

text:
My husband and I are both trying to lose weight so I'm putting together a low-cal cook book for us. I did change up a few things. Like safflower oil instead of olive oil and garlic powder instead of garlic salt (I'm not a fan of anything super salty). I did add about 1/4 teaspoon black lava sea salt from Hawaii. I used fresh tomatoes that were sitting around waiting. I also coated the chicken in all the seasonings before browning. And then added the balsamic vinegar after it was finished so that I could have the amount I liked vs the amount my husband likes. Served with a side of steamed broccoli. Yummmm.

text:
I love that this recipe packs a great flavor punch without a lot of preparation. In fact, maybe a teeny bit too much punch.  I adore balsamic vinegar, but did find that it was the only ingredient I could taste and the other yummy ingredients had been relegated to just interesting texture.  I do think that it could be partially due to the very high quality balsamic vinegar that I used, so I gave the recipe 4 stars instead of 3.  I would recommend cutting back the balsamic vinegar quantity a little though.  All in all, great dinner that can even be thrown together on a weeknight.

text:
I made this recipe tonight almost exactly as written, except I didn't have rosemary so left it out. I thought I had a large bottle of balsamic vinegar with a small amount in the bottom, but I was wrong. I had a bottle of less-than-perfect, store-brand stuff. I have no idea how it got into my pantry but I'm thinking someone must have given it to my husband (the never-throw-anything-out kind of guy) and he brought it home, put it away, thinking I'd think I had bought it. Anyway, I did have a balsamic glaze made from Balsamic Vinegar from Modena. I used this but slightly diluted with chicken broth. It is to die for good. Back to the recipe.... it turned out incredible. I did add a tablespoon of brown sugar to balance out the sweet/sour/savory thing. I served it with steamed rice. Will I make it again? You bet - in a heart-beat. It was super easy, economical, and tasted like heaven.

Love, love, love this. It was simple enough for a weeknight, but so flavorful. The chicken was moist and delicious. The only changes I made were that I sauteed my onions in a separate pan with a little butter (because there just wasn't room in the pan with the chicken), and after the chicken was cooked, I sliced it into tender-like pieces. The whole family loved this, from the 3-year-old to grandma! This will definitely be in heavy rotation for us!

text:
My family loved this!  I used World Market balsamic vinegar and followed the recipe with the following changes.  After 10 minutes of simmering, I cut the chicken into smaller pieces to soak up more liquid.  Then I simmered for 10 more minutes.  I wanted a thicker sauce so I mixed some of the liquid with cornstarch.  My son went back for thirds.

text:
I LOVED this.  Not sure if it made a difference, but the diced tomatoes I used were already flavored with garlic and onions.  I thought the dish was perfectly balanced with great flavors.  And, easy one pot cooking.

After reading the reviews where people said it was too balsamic-y, I asked my husband if he liked it. He came up with the same comment, that it was too balsamic-y.  

We ate the same meal, but his side dish was pasta with more of the braised balsamic sauce piled on it.  

I ate plain rice with my chicken, and it was perfect!  I thought about it every day for a week & bought the ingredients to make it again.

So, although the balsamic sauce is yummy, a little goes a long way.

Made this tonite for dinner and it was a WIN! My fiance and I loved it. I even gave our 1 yr old a taste and got a big smile. Our neighbors actually made thid for us after I came home from delivery, I had been wanting to make it ever since I just thought it was gonna be extremely hard but this recipe was super easy and your company wouldnt even know it. the only thing different I used was 2 tablespoons of sugar it mellowed out strong tart taste while not taking away from the flavor of the vinegar. I really enjoyed making this recipe I will definitely be making it again.

text:
Great recipe! Easy and quick to make with ingredients always in the house. I used fresh garlic and Rosemary because they were available. Halved the vinegar and used twice as much diced tomatoes as I had a large can and I don't like to waste. I served it over baby potatoes with a healthy scoop of sour cream. As well, added some sautéed mushrooms, cauliflower and kale to be lazy and make it a one pot dish. I can't imagine messing this one up! Highly recommend it especially when pinched for time and you want a healthy meal.

text:
I made this recipe twice. The first time I made it directly from the directions and I did not like it. Since the reviews were so positive I decided to give it another try with better balsamic and fresh herbs. I took several suggestions from other reviews which made the dish delicious. I mixed the sauce in a bowl and adjusted the seasonings and vinegar according to taste. I also added some chicken broth. I used at least twice the fresh basil but less thyme and rosemary than the recipe called for. I still thought it was too much rosemary. I used dried oregano but also did not use all that was called for. I served this with broccoli and a tomato basil quinoa. It was delicious.

text:
This recipe was delicious and worthy of serving to company! The Balsamic vinegar gave it a rich flavor, but was not over powering at all. With the vinegar and tomatoes I was worried about it being too acidic so I added a tsp. of sugar to the vinegar before adding it to the dish. I used McCormick grinder Italian seasoning to the chicken before browning it. I served it with Basmati rice and asparagus. My picky teenagers thought I was serving them a "fancy smancy" meal and yet it was so easy and they LOVED it!!

None
text:
This recipe is delicious! I doubled the sauce, so there was plenty to serve over pasta. I recommend a few changes. Season the chicken with salt and pepper. Cook the onions with minced garlic before adding the chicken. That way the onions get nice and soft. After you add the ingredients for the sauce, let it simmer on low/med for 45 min until the sauce thickens. It won't be too tangy, and it even tastes a little sweet.

text:
Made this for company and it worked out so well. It's so easy that I plan on making it again and again. Some notes: it is important to use a decent sweet balsamic vinegar. I like Lucini, Monari Federzoni, or Colavita for the supermarket brands. Also, Muir Glen organic fire roasted diced tomatoes added nice flavor. They are so much more flavorful than other canned tomatoes. Finally, I have a 12-inch skillet and 4 chicken breast-halves just fit, even though the recipe is for 6. Luckily I was just cooking for 4 guests. I could not find any smaller skinless breast-halves at the supermarket that would fit 6 in a skillet.

Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-01-05T22:55:20.19

text:
I made this dish for my boyfriend tonight and he loved it! We are both a fan of tangy flavor so this was right on the money. He loves mushrooms so I added them in with the onions. I plated this over some angel hair pasta tossed with olive oil and some Parmesan. There was plenty of sauce to drizzle all over! Very quick and easy for a large flavor payoff.

text:
I think some people don't like an overwhelming taste of balsamic vinegar which is why they don't like this recipe. You can always tone it down by decreasing the vinegar and adding a neutral ingredient such as cream (I made mine creamy with a few chunks of cream cheese). This will give you a juicy sauce to add in pasta to tone the balsamic down some more.... that's what I did and it was a hit.

This is a "go to" recipe for me! I've made this dish several times and it always turns out amazing. I have even tweaked it to use it as a homemade marinara sauce. Its a really great flavor! I wasn't sure at first if I would like the balsamic taste but trust me that the balsamic flavor really rounds this dish out nicely. I do recommend grinding the rosemary or finely chopping it. Its never fun to take a bite and get pricked by a piece of dried rosemary!

Love this dish. Made some modifications. Used fresh copped basil, minced garlic, and instead of the spices in this recipe I just seasoned with Italian seasoning. I used Italian stewed tomatoes. That way people can have as much or as little balsamic. Also melted mozzarella cheese over it.

OMG this was sooooooooooooooooo good. I made mine a little different, but it came out excellent! DON'T CHANGE A THING! One of the only recipes I have made exactly as stated, and it couldn't have come out better! Everyone loved it, including my picky eaters! It made a beautiful presentation served over wilted spinach. I wish I'd taken a picture to share! Will definitely keep in our regular rotation, and its wonderful for guests as well! I was worried about the spices and almost halved them as others had done, and I'm SO glad I didn't! I was also hesitant about the balsalmic vinegar from other reviews but bought a good one and stuck with the recipe as stated! DON'T CHANGE A THING! THANKS FOR A DELICIOUS AND EASY-TO-PREPARE MEAL!!!!!

I admit I did make some small changes.  I halved the recipe, lessened the balsamic vinegar, and mixed it with low sodium, low fat chicken broth.  I didn't really measure just went based on taste.  I also added about a tbsp of brown sugar to the mixture and used all of the other ingredients from the recipe.  I put it together with mashed potatoes and broccoli and it was absolutely phenomenal!  Very easy, quick, and tasty.  Thanks!

Made this recipe last night it  was so refreshing and light . I only made a couple small changes  . First I sliced the chicken before I cooked it because I was putting it with spaghettini . I only have garlic powder in the house so I used that . I only had 1/4 cup of balsamic vinegar so used chicken broth and added extra since I wanted lots of sauce for the spaghettini . It was great definitely will be making this again . Did the mixing of tomatoes, herbs and vinegar & broth in a bowl first like suggested by another review .

I thought this was allright. I saw it on a menu on the main page for daily meal plans at 1200 calories or less and decided to try it. I only had sweet pepper Italian chicken sausage, so I used that. One must really like balsamic vinegar to enjoy this, as that is the dominant taste. It is an acquired taste. The only other change I made was reducing the dried basil way back, as I don't care for it and shortening the cook time by 5 minutes due to using a pre-cooked chicken product.

text:
I recently found out that my daughter has a dairy protein allergy and being married to an Italian, it's been extremely hard to find good recipes. I made this tonight for my family of 5 and I wish I read the reviews prior with cutting down on the Balsamic as it was pretty strong but still very tasty. I did make some changes to our liking...instead of garlic salt, I used chopped fresh garlic and I seasoned the chicken with some seasoning instead of just pepper. I served the chicken with peas, corn, and mashed potatoes...everyone enjoyed this tasty meal. Next time, I will definitely be cutting down on the balsamic vinegar. Thanks for sharing!!

text:
THIS WAS AMAZING!!!! I did add a few ingredients. I marinated all the ingredients, except for the olive oil, chicken, and onions in a bowl for about 4 hours.  I didn't have a can of diced tomatoes, so i cut up two softball sized tomatoes in chunks. I also added one small can of tomato paste to the marinade and 1 tsp of brown sugar. I didn't have rosemary, so I just omitted that.  I put the bowl of marinade in with the cooked chicken, olive oil, and onions. While the sauce and chicken were simmering, I added 1/4 cup of Holland House white cooking wine. The taste was so good, I had it for dinner the nest night!

text:
Found this recipe to be one we wanted to make again. The first time, I used Italian seasoning in lieu of the separate herbs and finely-minced scallions in place of the onion. This time, we're making it with a locally-sourced Italian herb-infused olive oil and regular onions. Didn't change anything else. About the only tip I have is to brown the chicken breasts on med-high heat to sear them and retain juices, and drop the heat to medium or so to simmer with the liquid. Otherwise - this one's going in my permanent rotation. And I'm not even a big fan of Balsamic =)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2411077.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't follow the recipe to a T because I read reviews and made adjustments - but maaan, this dish is so good I make it pretty regularly because it's so easy. First, I caramelize the onions in butter for about 15 minutes, adding brown sugar and ground black pepper the last 5 minutes.  Meanwhile, I have chicken marinated in balsamic vinegar (you don't have to, I just do to make it easier to throw together) - add the chicken in and then the tomatoes and basil.  I don't have the other spices, but it turns out fine.  I like how you really can't mess up this dish - sometimes I add chopped green onions to the mix, other times if I have some cilantro on hand, I throw it in.  It's also good with mushrooms, or without.  Good over rice or with some somen noodles.  Thanks!

text:
This was delicious.  I used a combination of legs (6) and breasts (3).  I cut each breast into about 5 pieces and when it was about done, I cut those pieces into smaller, bite-sized pieces and let it simmer about 5 more minutes.  I used 2 cans of Italian flavored stewed tomatoes and a can of tomato sauce.  The sauce was a bit thin when it was done, so I added some flour to the mixture to thicken it up a bit and served it over angel hair pasta.  It was a hit with the entire family.

text:
This was great - quick, easy, and tasty! 

All I used was chicken, olive oil, onion, balsamic vinegar, italian seasoned tomatoes and rather than garlic salt I used a dab of miced garlic. 

Super easy and very yummy!! 

I would recommend putting the onions in for a minute or so alone prior to adding chicken. Some of mine weren't cooked as well as the others.

text:
My fiance and I loved this recipe!! I did make some changes to it as others had suggested. Otherwise it would've been a 5 star. Changes I made were: When browning the onions add fresh minced garlic instead of garlic salt, use only 1/4 C of balsamic, use 1/2 tsp of basil, oregano and rosemary and mix the spices and balsamic together before adding to the chicken. This is a definite keeper in the recipe book!! Enjoy! :)

text:
Really tasty dish.  I used a nice balsamic that a friend left (thank you Annie), and it was fantastic.  I sauteed the onions first and set them aside after a mild carmelization.  Then, after tenderizing my 3 large chicken breasts, browned those independently cooking about 2/3 through.  After that, added back the onions and added the rest of the ingredients (subbing Homemade Italian Season I from allrecipes for the independent spices) and let it stew.  The outer portion of the chicken absorbed the wet ingredients beautifully, so with the two extra breasts (I'm a bachelor), I chopped the remaining chicken and added it back, and am certain tomorrow will provide proof of tonight's happy marriage.

text:
This recipe is really yummy, I had to add a little salt, pepper, onion and garlic powder to the sauce to give it an extra kick. Added egg noddles to the pot so they soaked up the extra juices and I am telling you it was superb, will try this again with chicken thighs as my breasts dried out a bit (probably my fault though). Also, I browned all the chicken first this added the onions to the leftover juices and browned them then added the chicken back in layering the onions in between them. Perfecto!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this several times now and love it each time! I have sauteed fresh chopped eggplant and zucchinni (tis the season) with onion... I've thrown in fresh garlic and tons of fresh chopped herbs (basil- lots of rosemary - thyme - oregano). If you add another can or tomatoes (w/a bit of water to thin it) you can get enough sauce to put it over angel hair pasta... some crusty bread and salad and you have a gourmet dinner!  I love it with garlic mashed and sauteed green beans.  I've made a lot for company too... just caramelize your onions - pan sear your chicken - then layer it in a large rectangle baking dish... mix up the tomato mixture and pour it over... top it with foil and put it in over for a half hour on 350.  Possibilities are endless : ) Thanks so much for this awesome recipe!

text:
As other reviewers mentioned, I added a few things to this recipe. First, I only used 3 chicken breats and cut them into chunks. I browned them first then added the onions until carmelized, then added sliced fresh buttom mushrooms until they were brown, then a large clove of minced garlic. At that point, I added the tomatoes, balsamic (excellent quality, thick and sweet), a little chicken stock, the herbs, and a can of baby artichoke hearts. I let it simmer covered for about 20 minutes then served over angel hair pasta and topped it with fresh grated parmessan. You'd think it would be amazing but to me and my husband something seemed like it was missing and it wasn't out of the ballpark like I thought it would be. The next day, leftovers were a little better but overall it's probably not a dish I'll make again.

text:
This dish can easily be made into a meal all by itself. I have fixed this for my boyfriend and myself several times. To turn it into an entire meal I first cut two organic chicken breasts into bite size pieces, then cook them with half a sliced onion, minced garlic and a cup of sliced portabella mushrooms. I then add in an entire can of organic diced tomatoes, the balsamic and seasonings. Super low calorie and full of veggies and protein! I serve this with a side of steamed green beans. Less than 500 calories per serving and DELICIOUS!

text:
Loved it!  My three year old actually asked for more - this never happens.  It's still a hit - I've learned this cooks best in my cast iron skillet (so I can get it to a medium/high heat when initially braising the chicken) and I also cut the chicken into medallions so they absorb more of the balsamic vinegar and seasoning flavor.  It cooks more quickly too.  I definitely took another reviewers suggestion about adding just a pinch of brown sugar to the mix to reduce the bite of the vinegar - it makes it delicious!

text:
Delicious, and the best part is, this dinner was SO easy to make! My husband liked it a lot. He had his over some angel hair pasta and I had mine over some leftover jasmine rice (my favorite). I used 2 cloves of fresh garlic along with the garlic salt (we are garlic fans around here). I also only used one large chicken breast half, cut into strips before cooking. Also added a pinch of brown sugar to cut down on the tartness, and only 1/4 cup of balsamic vinegar, per the other reviewers suggestions. Excellent, easy dinner, perfect enough for a weeknight but good enough to serve to company, too.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only way my 10 year old will eat chicken breast.  I blended advice from several reviewers to make this more kid friendly.  I cut the chicken into chunks to make it easier to eat and allow people more flexible serving sizes.  I cut out the recommended spices and used Italian tomatoes and 3 cloves of crushed garlic.  I used only 1/4 cup balsamic vinegar and added 1/4 cup chicken broth.  I also covered the pan for half the cooking time to assure all of the chicken was cooked.  I served this over brown rice for some and pasta for others along with roasted asparagus and salad.  This was a super easy week day meal that I will definitely serve again.  Thanks for a great recipe!

This was a good recipe. I added an extra can of tomatoes to make more sauce. I had to cook my chicken longer because I used thick breasts. The only other thing I did differently was add about 2 tablespoons of cornstarch mixed with cold water to thicken the sauce. My family loved this served over angel hair pasta. This was a quick and easy recipe.

text:
Great flavour! I did make a few changes though. I followed the advice of one of the other reviewers who suggested adding some chicken stock to mellow out the flavour of the sauce. It was a great idea and really rounded out the flavours in the tomato sauce.  I added a teaspoon of sugar to lessen the zing of the tomatoes and balsamic.  And, finally, I added some chilli flakes, just because I prefer a little heat in my dishes.  Great recipe - I will definitely make this a part of my regular line up.

text:
The only reason I give this a 4 instead of 5 is personal taste - I like balsamic to an extent but don't love it.  For people who do love balsamic, I am sure this will get 5 stars.  The only thing different I did to this was add a bit of fresh minced garlic.  This recipe was very easy and took minimal time.  I served it with steamed broccoli - some of the sauce from the chicken got on the broccoli and it was a perfect seasoning for the veggies.  I will more than likely make this again but will prob cut the balsamic with chicken stock next time for a more mild balsamic flavor.

text:
I had a headache already so when I saw the amount of spices, I decided to cut all by at least half. I had 4 chicken breasts and used 1/4 tsp garlic salt, about 2 cloves minced garlic, 1/4 cup balsamic vinegar,  1/8 tsp basil, 1/8 tsp oregano, pinch of rosemary and a pinch of thyme. With all the alterations, it was very tasty and not too overpowering. I'm not big on using spices so the modifications may not suit others.

text:
Just made this again, and it was delicious! I used actual garlic in the pan and regular salt on the chicken. I scaled the recipe down for 2 chicken breasts, since I was just cooking for me and my boyfriend. However, I ended up using the whole can of diced tomatoes because it all just kind of fell out when I poured it. I'm glad I used the whole can of tomatoes because I think the vinegar would be too strong otherwise. It turned out perfect, and the remaining sauce was great to dip my homemade focaccia bread in!

text:
This is hands down one of our favorite recipes!  My husband thinks it is as good as any chicken dish you would find in a fine restaurant, and he eats at a lot of great restaurants while traveling.  We always have the ingredients on hand, and it is a very quick dish to prepare.  I use whatever canned tomatoes I have and an italian seasoning blend instead of all the individual ones.  I serve over mashed potatoes (instant because I need shortcuts!), they soak up all the wonderful sauce.  Serve with your favorite vegetable and a glass of red wine, and you will feel like you are in your favorite restaurant!

userID:
3243554
Display Name:
LMF443
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/416193.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good, quick and easy.  I served this last night over rice.  I'm also a big fan of balsamic on broccoli, so I wanted to incorporate that into the dinner as well.  I marinated the chicken in the spices and a little bit of the vinegar.  I heated olive oil in a pan and put in the onions to sauté.  After a minute I threw on the chicken (dumped the whole marinating bag) and browned it lightly.  I then removed the chicken and threw on some broccoli (I hate when things overcook).  I sautéed the broccoli until it turned a bright green (so a minute or so) and removed it.  I then put the spices, vinegar, and tomato on the still cooking onion and let the sauce cook down for a while.  After it was a consistency I liked, I put on the chicken, let it cook the rest of the way through, turned off the heat, and added the broccoli and mixed it all together.  Whole thing took me less than a half hour!  There were no leftovers and my guests discovered that dipping Italian bread in the sauce was also a treat.  I will be making it again, although I think I will sauté mushrooms and add some brown sugar to cut down on that vinegar aftertaste. YUM!

text:
I originally gave this recipes 4 stars as written but am upgrading it to 5 with a substitution I discovered. I substituted the canned tomatos for 3 very large roma tomatos (chopped and seeded) and one tablespoon julienned sundried tomatos. I use fresh garlic (minced) and 1/4 c basalmic (use good quality - garbage in, garbage out ya know). I also cooked slowly with the lid off at the end to reduce the liquid and intensify the flavors. It was outrageously good! Oh, and I dice the chicken so it cooks faster. Biggest critics love it: 2 yr old to picky brother-in-law. Try with risotto.

The balsamic is a little overpowering in this dish.  Must use a high quality vinegar to get the right taste.   I did cut back on the spices, 1/2 t of each basil and oregano, and rosemary and only 1/8 of tyme.  Can't imagine using full amounts, this was just right.  Overall I would make this again.

This chicken was fantastic! I changed it a little bit to suit our tastes. I cut the chicken into bite size pieces to stretch it a little farther and chopped the onions instead of slicing. I only used about an 1/8 cup of balsamic vinegar and replaced the rest with some vegetable broth I had on hand. I also decreased the amount of rosemary. We had it over penne and it was fantastic! I'll definitely make this again and again!

YUM YUM YUM!  And so easy it was almost embarassing!  I didn't follow the recipe exactly, but then again I rarely do!  I omitted the onion (heartburn!) and dry herbs.  I used canned diced tomatoes that has herbs already mixed in, but did use salt and pepper on the chicken and some fresh basil.  I sauteed a little garlic in the oil before browning the chicken and used boneless skinless thighs instead of breasts, since that is what I had defrosted. 

I served this with tomato-lentil cous-cous and sauteed zucchini.  It was delish!  Thanks a ton!

text:
I made this for the first time for a dinner party at my home!  Luckily, it was delicious!  I, too, was concerned about the amount of vinegar.  I kept the amount of vinegar, but added 1/2 cup of chicken broth to cut the tang of vinegar.  I substituted mushrooms for tomatoes and cut out the rosemary and thyme.  Served over rice with green beans and beer bread (from this site), our guests were thrilled!  This is a new staple for my family!

text:
This is a good concept but in my opinion needed a lot of help.  With some modifications, however, it is wonderful.  I took the advice of others and only used 1/4 c. balsamic, and also added 1/4 c. chicken stock.  When the chicken was done, I took it out and added 3 t. splenda to sweeten the sauce as it otherwise is too bitter -- and I love balsamic vinegar.  I then added cornstock to thicken the sauce, then added a can of mushrooms.  I served the mixture over pasta and it turned out excellent.  With the modifications, the sauce is rich and irresistable.

text:
Made this recipe with no alterations, though I didn't measure the spices, just eyeballed it. Oh, and I omitted the garlic, since my husband thinks he's allergic (he's not, he just doesn't like it, and won't eat if he knows it's in there!) We enjoyed it, served over pasta. I'm making it again tonight (this time I'll be adding some garlic, I now think it's a necessary addition) and may also add mushrooms as others have done. I will also serve it over med. grain rice this time, as we thought the texture of the onions and pasta were too similar. Great recipe though, and one that's going in the long rotation.

None
text:
This recipe was a fantastic guideline for a very simple and quick but VERY tasty dish! I didn't follow any of the measurements but eyeballed everything and the flavors all just seemed to compliment each other.  I added extra onions and lots of sliced mushrooms before adding the diced tomatoes and also added enough vinegar to darken the contents of the pan considerably - my boyfriend loves balsamic vinegar.  It simmered for more than 15-20 mins but on a low heat it kept the chicken moist and the sauce that came together had a chance to thicken a bit.  I broiled asparagus in olive oil and salt and mixed it with tagliatelle pasta.  The chicken served on top and ta dah - DEEElish.  Thanks for a great recipe.  SO easy and flexible - will def make it again!

country:
None
text:
A couple of really good things about this recipe is that it's so quick to make and it's list of ingredients are things that are always on hand in a fairly well stocked kitchen.  The only change I made was to add  mushrooms and I think that was a fine addition.  My chicken was slightly overcooked - and that happened in a blink of an eye so make sure you keep an eye on it. It did NOT take 15 minutes for me. More like 10 or 11 and my chicken breasts were not thin either. Very aromatic and extremely tasty. We served it with white rice and steamed veggies on the side. The onions in this recipe are wonderful - next time I might add a whole other onion. If you are looking for a quick meal to prepare and cook - this is it.  Very quick, nutritional and delicious.

Scaled back to 2 servings and substituted 1/2 a fresh tomato for the canned tomatoes. Cubed the chicken before cooking. Omitted the onion, garlic salt, and rosemary. Kept the balsamic vinegar the same amount.  I used the sweet balsamic vinegar, it has a wonderful taste. Turned up the heat at the end to thicken the sauce which turned out perfectly. Not too salty, too sweet, or too vinegary. Very good dish that needs only a few ingredients. Will make again soon. Thanks!

text:
Very tasty! I scaled it down to four servings my first time, two servings my second time. I've served it over buttered spaghetti and whole wheat linguini; I personally think the linguni holds up a little better for it.  I put a little splash of maple syrup in to cut any vinegary-tang, but I did use the full amount of vinegar.  I think I'll try doubling the sauce, because it's so darn tasty!  Might pound my breasts thin, too; I had to add a little water to the pan because my really thick chicken still needed cooking while the liquid was almost gone.  A company-worthy dish that earned a thumbs-up from my husband.

text:
I followed the suggestions and used 1/4c vinegar, 1/4c chicken broth. I skipped the herbs and did not miss them in the finished product. The tomato/onion/vinegar sauce pairs well with rice (also cooked in chicken broth). I've never cooked with more than a tablespoon of balsamic vinegar before, and I am surprised how long the flavor lingers in my mouth. If you are unsure how you will enjoy the balsamic flavor, I suggest going for a 3 to 1 ratio of broth to vinegar. Will make again though! Great and simple pantry-staple recipe

This recipe was very flavorful, but too much for our family. The spices and balsamic vinegar were overpowering. If I made this again, I would cut the spices back by at least half and substitute half the balsamic vinegar with chicken broth. Everyone else seemed to love it, so maybe it's just my family that thought the flavors were too overwhelming. I did love how healthy this recipe was, though.

text:
Easy and great taste.  I used halved fresh cherry tomatoes.  Since I didn't have any plain balsamic vinegar, I let a bottle of balsamic vinagrette seperate, then used a turkey plunger to extract the oil (on top) for step one, then the balsamic (on the bottom) for step two.  I'd advise others to use too little rather than too much thyme and taste it before adding the salt.

Made this again in 2015.  I suggest thinly slicing (not dicing) red onion.  I am using the leftover sauce and vegetables to marinade another chicken breast.

text:
I actually forgot to add the canned tomatoes and panicked, thinking to myself that the chicken would taste too much like balsamic vinegar. Alas! I used maybe a 1/4 to 1/3 cup of balsamic vinegar, adding the minced garlic just before dropping in pan to prevent tburning, and it came out delicious. I served it with a flavored couscous and sauteed fresh vegetables (carrots, cauliflower, broccoli and green beans).

I found this to be bit too tangy for my tastes the first time I made it, so I added 2 Tbsps brown sugar to cut it down a bit.  I also added 1 tsp paprika and 1/8 tsp cayenne.  That really helped, but the balsamic flavor was still a little strong, so next time I'll cut back on the vinegar and add chicken stock to top up to the 1/2 cup. Very nice recipe - thank you!

I noticed that one reviewer said the recipe lacked "zip" and another said that if cooking for fewer people, do not reduce the sauce as it is very good.  I was cooking for two and cooked one breast and two thighs.  I used a 10 oz can of Rotel Mild Diced Tomatoes and Green Chilis.  I did reduce the balsamic as suggested to a bit over 1/4 cup as the tomatoes came in a 10 oz can.  I also reduced the herbs to a scant 1 tsp as called for.  It was superb.  I definitely will serve this again.   Had PLENTY of sauce for more chicken so if you are cooking for 4 this should work.

This dish was amazing. I made a couple of adjustments as suggested by other reviewers. I cubed four chicken breasts. I diced one large fresh tomato.
